questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of nausea and shortness of breath that started while he was at work 1 hour ago. He also reports lightheadedness that started earlier in the day. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin and sitagliptin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He appears pale and diaphoretic. A 12-lead ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An acute posterior myocardial infarction (MI) can be diagnosed based on the presence of ST elevations on special leads V7–V9. On a standard 12-lead ECG, a posterior MI manifests with reciprocal ST depression in leads V1–V4 or an R:S wave ratio > 1 in leads V1 and V2 due to an increase in the R wave amplitude. This patient only has an ST depression in lead V2 and an R:S ratio < 1 in leads V1 and V2. It is therefore unlikely that this patient has had a posterior wall MI.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ~ 83/min
– Sinus rhythm
– Normal axis (R > S in I and II)
– Downsloping ST depression in leads V2 and V3 and horizontal ST depression in V4 (examples indicated by red overlay) is accompanied by positive T waves (examples indicated by blue overlay). This appearance is reciprocal to posterior ST elevations with T-wave inversions.
– Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2 (example indicated by green overlay): reciprocal to posterior Q waves
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): rSR′ complex in V1 and QRS duration of 0.12 s

These findings suggest a posterior myocardial infarction. To confirm, an additional ECG including the posterior leads V7–V9 can be obtained to look for ST elevation, T-wave inversion, and Q waves. Note that ST depression ≥ 0.5 mm in leads V1–V4 is a STEMI-equivalent ECG finding (i.e., management is the same as that for STEMI).

B) INCORRECT:

Viral myocarditis can cause dyspnea and nonspecific ST elevations on ECG, but it is typically be preceded by a viral prodrome, with fever, myalgia, and upper respiratory symptoms. This patient has no history of a preceding viral infection, making viral myocarditis an unlikely diagnosis. Furthermore, his ECG findings are more consistent with a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A patient with ventricular fibrillation is typically unresponsive, with an ECG showing disorganized, high-frequency (usually > 300/min), sawtooth-like waves with indiscernible P waves or QRS complexes. This patient is responsive, with distinct P waves as well as QRS complexes and a heart rate of 60–70/min on ECG.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– No discernible P waves, QRS complexes, or T waves
– Absence of the normal isoelectric baseline
– Chaotic irregular deflections representing disorganized electrical activity in the ventricles with a rate of ∼ 375/min

Diagnosis: ventricular fibrillation. Note that this rhythm results in loss of cardiac output and is fatal unless resuscitation is rapidly commenced.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute pericarditis can cause shortness of breath and ST elevations on ECG. However, the ST elevations in pericarditis typically occur diffusely in all leads, in contrast to this patient's ECG findings. Moreover, clinical features such as fever, a pericardial friction rub, and/or retrosternal chest pain are expected in a patient with acute pericarditis.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

Sinus tachycardia with a frequency of approx. 107/min.
Normal heart axis (R > S in both I and aVF).
P waves have normal morphology. Diffuse PR depressions with reciprocal, concave ST elevations (best seen in aVL) and PR elevations in aVR. Note the notching at the end of the QRS complexes (creating the “fish hook” morphology; best seen in aVL). Discordant T wave in V1.
PR interval normal (approx. 120 ms), QRS interval borderline narrow (approx. 80 ms), QT interval prolonged (approx. 400 ms; QTc = 534 ms).

These findings are typical for stage 1 in acute pericarditis.

E) CORRECT:

Acute inferior myocardial infarction (MI) is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with dyspnea, lightheadedness, ST elevation in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF), and reciprocal ST depression in leads I and aVL. This patient has significant risk factors for atherosclerotic disease, including type 2 diabetes mellitus and a 20 pack-year smoking history. Acute STEMI is usually diagnosed based on the initial ECG and the presence of typical ischemic chest pain. However, diabetic patients and elderly women may have an atypical presentation with little or no chest pain and predominantly autonomic symptoms (e.g., nausea).

F) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation can manifest with nausea, shortness of breath, and light-headedness. However, in the case of atrial fibrillation, the ECG shows a variable RR interval and absent P waves. This patient has a constant RR interval and clearly discernible P waves on ECG, making atrial fibrillation unlikely.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm

– Average ventricular rate is ∼ 144/min (24 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

G) INCORRECT:

A saddle pulmonary embolism can manifest with shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and nonspecific ST elevations on ECG. However, this patient is lacking features of right ventricular strain on ECG (e.g., S1Q3T3 pattern, increased R wave amplitude, and ST depression in V1 and V2) and the absence of tachycardia and major risk factors (e.g., prolonged immobilization, recent trauma, surgery, malignancy) make this diagnosis unlikely. This patient's ECG findings are more consistent with a different etiology.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Normal rate (approx. 90/min)
– Cardiac axis ∼ 90° (QRS complex is isoelectric in I and positive in aVF): borderline normal/right-axis deviation
– P pulmonale: P-wave amplitude ≥ 0.25 mV in II, III, and aVF
– PR interval normal (< 0.2 s)
– QRS duration 0.1–0.12 s (incomplete bundle branch block)
– QTc interval normal (∼ 0.4 s)
– Discordant T-wave inversion in III, aVR, V1, V3–V6
– SIQIIITIII-pattern: deep S waves in I (blue overlay), pathological Q waves in III (green overlay), and T-wave inversion in III (red overlay)

The SIQIIITIII-pattern and P pulmonale are both suggestive of pulmonary embolism, but neither of these findings is sensitive or specific for this diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

A second-degree AV block can manifest as either a Mobitz type 1 or a Mobitz type 2 block. Mobitz type 1 manifests with a progressive prolongation of the PR interval that culminates in a nonconducted P wave (“dropped beat”) on ECG. Mobitz type 2 AV block is characterized by a constant PR interval and a single or intermittent nonconducted P wave without subsequent QRS complexes. This patient's ECG shows P waves before every QRS complex and a constant PR interval.
Image Description:

ECG schematic of types of second-degree atrioventricular block (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– P waves occur at a regular rate of ∼78/min in all tracings.
– Mobitz I/Wenckebach (top): There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.
– 2:1 block (middle): The PR interval is constant but only every second P wave is conducted to the ventricles to trigger a QRS complex.
– High-grade block (bottom): The PR interval is constant but ≥2 consecutive P waves are not conducted to the ventricles. In this example, only every third P wave triggers a QRS complex (a 3:1 block).
questions.hint: The ECG shows ST elevations in II, III, and aVF.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of nausea and retrosternal chest pain. She has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her current medications include atorvastatin, metformin, and lisinopril. She is diaphoretic. Her serum troponin level is 3.0 ng/mL (N: < 0.04). She undergoes cardiac catheterization. A photograph of coronary angiography performed prior to percutaneous coronary intervention is shown. An acute myocardial infarction associated with the finding on angiography is most likely to manifest with ST elevations in which of the following leads on ECG?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ST elevations in leads I and aVR are an atypical finding because these leads do not correspond with any specific territory of the heart that is supplied by a single artery. This patient's coronary angiography study shows severe occlusion of the LAD.

B) INCORRECT:

ST elevations in leads V3R–V6R on ECG typically develop as a result of infarcts that involve the right coronary artery and its branches, which supply the inferior aspect of the heart (e.g., right ventricle). This patient's coronary angiography study shows severe occlusion of the proximal LAD, which does not typically affect these leads.

C) CORRECT:

ST elevations typically develop in leads V1–V6 on ECG as a result of infarcts that involve the proximal LAD. Leads V1–V2 correspond to the anteroseptal territory; leads V3–V4 correspond to the anteroapical territory; leads V5–V6 correspond to the anterolateral territory. In some cases, ST elevations in the lateral leads (leads I and aVL) can also develop.
Image Description:

The obtuse marginal artery is also known as the left marginal artery, and the acute marginal artery is also known as the right marginal artery.

D) INCORRECT:

ST elevations typically develop in leads II, III, and aVF on ECG as a result of infarcts that involve the right coronary artery, which supplies the inferior aspect of the heart. This patient's coronary angiography study shows severe occlusion of the LAD, which does not typically affect these leads.

E) INCORRECT:

ST elevations typically develop in leads V7–V9 on ECG as a result of infarcts that involve the posterior descending artery, which supplies the posterior aspect of the heart. This patient's coronary angiography study shows severe occlusion of the LAD, which does not typically affect these leads.
questions.hint: This patient's coronary angiography study shows proximal narrowing of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. This artery perfuses the anterior surface of the heart: two-thirds of the interventricular septum, the anterolateral papillary muscle, and the anterior surface of the left ventricle.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of retrosternal chest pressure and shortness of breath for 4 hours. The symptoms started while he was walking to work and have only minimally improved with rest. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He appears uncomfortable. His pulse is 95/min. Serum studies show a normal troponin concentration. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Coronary artery occlusion due to transient increase in vascular tone
Stable atherosclerotic plaque with 85% coronary artery occlusion
Infarction and rupture of a papillary muscle
Disruption of an atherosclerotic plaque with a nonocclusive coronary artery thrombus
Atherosclerotic plaque thrombus with complete coronary artery occlusion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve thickening and calcification result in aortic stenosis. This condition typically remains asymptomatic for years, but exertional angina and dyspnea can develop gradually as the aortic valve becomes increasingly stenotic. If the stenosis becomes severe, patients can experience symptoms at rest. Aortic stenosis is not likely to initially manifest with sudden-onset symptoms that do not improve with rest as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery occlusion due to a transient increase in vascular tone is the underlying pathology of vasospastic angina, which causes episodic angina and dyspnea at rest. Though vasospastic angina does not cause increased serum concentrations of cardiac biomarkers such as troponin, it is associated with reversible ST elevations on ECG, which are not seen in this patient. Moreover, episodes of angina caused by this condition typically last for 5–15 minutes. This patient has had 4 hours of progressive symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

A stable atherosclerotic plaque with significant occlusion of a coronary artery can cause stable angina pectoris, which manifests with exertional chest pain and dyspnea that resolve with rest. This patient's symptoms only minimally improved with rest. Moreover, a diagnosis of stable angina pectoris requires a history of prior episodes of anginal chest pain, and there is no indication that this patient has had similar episodes in the past.

D) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of myocardial infarction that most commonly develops 2–7 days after infarction and involves the mitral valve, which leads to sudden-onset hypotension and severe mitral regurgitation that can manifest with dyspnea. This complication would not develop in the acute phase of infarction.

E) CORRECT:

Disruption of an atherosclerotic plaque with a nonocclusive coronary artery thrombus can impair coronary artery perfusion and result in myocardial ischemia that causes unstable angina pectoris. This condition includes new-onset angina pectoris and angina pectoris that increases in frequency or severity over time. Symptoms typically persist for ≥ 20 minutes and can occur at rest or with minimal exertion as seen in this case. Unstable angina pectoris does not cause cardiac biomarker elevation. ECG can be normal or show ST depression and/or T-wave inversion.

F) INCORRECT:

An atherosclerotic plaque thrombus with complete coronary artery occlusion results in myocardial infarction (e.g., STEMI, NSTEMI), which manifests with chest pain and dyspnea. However, myocardial infarction causes increased serum concentrations of cardiac biomarkers such as troponin, which are not seen in this patient. Moreover, myocardial infarction is usually associated with characteristic ECG changes (e.g., ST elevation, ST depression).
questions.hint: This patient with multiple cardiovascular risk factors (older age, male sex, history of diabetes mellitus and smoking) has unstable angina pectoris, a condition that can cause chest pain and dyspnea at rest without cardiac biomarker elevation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is evaluated for sudden left arm pain 7 days after being admitted to the hospital for anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction, which was treated with percutaneous coronary angioplasty and stenting of the distal left anterior descending artery. The sharp pain woke him up and he now is also complaining of numbness in the fingers and difficulty moving his arm. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include atorvastatin, aspirin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and clopidogrel. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. His left arm is cool to touch and pale, and the left radial pulse is not palpable. Muscle strength is 1/5 in the left upper extremity and 5/5 in all other extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture typically occurs 2–7 days after myocardial infarction (MI), similar to what is seen here. However, papillary muscle rupture often leads to severe mitral regurgitation, which manifests with dyspnea, cough, bilateral crackles, and hypotension, none of which this patient has. Furthermore, papillary muscle rupture is less likely in a patient with a single-vessel anterior wall MI, because the anterolateral papillary muscle has a dual blood supply from the left circumflex and left anterior descending arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome) usually occurs 2–10 weeks after a myocardial infarction (MI) and can manifest with pleuritic or pericardial chest pain that can radiate to the arm. This patient has no chest pain; his left arm pain with poikilothermia, paresthesia, pulselessness, and paresis suggests acute upper limb ischemia, not Dressler syndrome. Further, patients with Dressler syndrome typically present with fever and a dry cough, neither of which is seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Iatrogenic left brachial arterial injury can occur during percutaneous coronary angioplasty and lead to dissection or thrombosis and ischemia of the arm. However, this complication manifests acutely and is unlikely to occur 7 days after the procedure.

D) CORRECT:

Mural thromboembolism from a left ventricular pseudoaneurysm is the most likely cause of this patient's acute limb ischemia. A left ventricular pseudoaneurysm typically develops 3–14 days after myocardial infarction, and it can also lead to decreased cardiac output and arrhythmia. Initial diagnosis of a ventricular pseudoaneurysm is performed with transthoracic echocardiography, but a definitive diagnosis is determined with angiography, which allows direct visualization of the lesion.

Mural thromboembolism can also be associated with a true ventricular aneurysm. As true ventricular aneurysm typically develops 2 weeks to a few months postinfarction, this patient is more likely to have a ventricular pseudoaneurysm (see “Overview of MI complications” table).

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal rupture can occur as a complication of myocardial infarction and usually develops 3–5 days post-infarction. Ventricular septal rupture leads to acute right heart failure, which can progress to cardiogenic shock and manifest with cool extremities. However, patients with right heart failure and cardiogenic shock also present with jugular venous distension, peripheral edema, tachycardia, hypotension, and altered mental status, none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: Presentation with acute left arm pain, poikilothermia, paresthesia, pulselessness, and paresis is consistent with acute limb ischemia.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening shortness of breath on exertion and increased urinary frequency at night. During this time, he has used 2 pillows at night to avoid waking up from a dry cough and dyspnea. Three months ago, he had a myocardial infarction that was treated with placement of a stent in the left anterior descending artery. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 5 years ago. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, enalapril, and insulin. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, a grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the left sternal border. There is an S3 gallop. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard over the lung base bilaterally. ECG shows persistent ST elevations and deep Q waves in leads V1 through V4. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ventricular aneurysms can develop several weeks to months after an MI because of scar tissue formation that leads to thinning and weakening of the ventricular wall. This in turn can lead to congestive heart failure, which is a common complication of ventricular aneurysms. Other complications of ventricular aneurysms include myocardial wall rupture (which can lead to cardiac tamponade), arrhythmias, and mural thrombus formation within the aneurysmal segment (due to stasis of blood flow). Ventricular aneurysms typically manifest with a systolic murmur, an S3 and/or S4 gallop, and persistent ST elevations on ECG, all of which are seen here. Diagnosis is confirmed by visualization of the pathological myocardial wall protrusion on echocardiography.

See “Overview of MI complications” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture typically leads to mitral regurgitation, which causes a new holosystolic murmur, dyspnea, and pulmonary edema. However, papillary muscle rupture is an acute, life-threatening complication that manifests with hypotension, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation. Moreover, it usually occurs 2–7 days after an MI, whereas this patient's symptoms manifested 2 months after his MI.

C) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal rupture can occur after a left anterior descending artery (LAD) infarction and manifests with a new holosystolic murmur. However, the septal rupture leads to a left-to-right shunt and acute-onset right heart failure, which manifests with jugular venous distention and peripheral pitting edema, neither of which is seen here. Moreover, ventricular septal rupture typically manifests 3–5 days after an MI, whereas this patient's symptoms manifested 2 months after his MI.

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the right coronary artery can lead to inferior wall MI and right ventricular MI. This patient's history of coronary artery disease puts him at increased risk for reinfarction. However, MI typically manifests acutely with retrosternal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea and vomiting, none of which is seen here. Moreover, unlike the findings in this patient, inferior wall MI typically causes ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF, and right ventricular MI commonly manifests with hypotension and jugular venous distention without pulmonary edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome) is an acute form of pericarditis that can occur several weeks after an MI and manifest with a dry cough, dyspnea, and persistent ST elevations on ECG. However, ST elevations are typically seen in all leads, and deep Q waves in leads V1 through V4, as seen here, are not typical. Moreover, other features of acute pericarditis, such as pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub on auscultation, and low-grade fever, are absent.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (i.e., dyspnea, orthopnea, and nocturia) and signs of pulmonary edema (i.e., bilateral crackles) raise suspicion for congestive heart failure, which is most likely due to a late complication of myocardial infarction (MI).

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents for follow-up 3 weeks after experiencing an anterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction and receiving a drug-eluting stent in her proximal left anterior descending artery.
She has been participating in cardiac rehabilitation and was doing well until 6 days ago, when she started feeling sharp left-sided substernal chest pain. The pain waxes and wanes unpredictably throughout the day and is worse with inspiration and on lying down. She also reports an episode of subjective fever yesterday.
She has systolic dysfunction (left ventricular ejection fraction, 42%), hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Her medications are aspirin 81 mg, prasugrel 10 mg, atorvastatin 80 mg, extended-release metoprolol 50 mg, lisinopril 10 mg, and furosemide 20 mg, each taken once daily.
She has a low-grade fever of 37.7°C. Her heart rate is regular at 58 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 98% while she is breathing ambient air. She has no jugular venous distention. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. There are no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. She has no lower-extremity edema.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Creatine kinase (U/liter)
136
40–150


Creatine kinase MB isoenzyme (ng/mL)
3
0–7


Troponin T (ng/mL) (4th-generation assay)
0.01
0–0.03


Brain natriuretic peptide (pg/mL)
376
≤114


Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Hospitalize the patient and infuse unfractionated heparin
Initiate treatment with colchicine and full-dose aspirin
Repeat cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography
Order CT of the chest with a pulmonary embolism protocol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with PCIS should avoid non-aspirin nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and glucocorticoids (which are used for patients with other causes of pericarditis) because they impede myocardial healing.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulants, such as heparin, can increase the risks for hemorrhagic pericardial effusion and tamponade.

C) CORRECT:

Postcardiac injury syndrome (PCIS), or Dressler syndrome, develops in approximately 3% of patients in the weeks or months after a myocardial infarction. It consists of an inflammatory response with immune-complex deposition in the pericardium and lung pleura and is characterized by pleuritic chest pain, fever, and occasionally a pericardial rub and effusion. Characteristic electrocardiographic changes include diffuse PR-segment depression or ST-segment elevation.

Conservative treatment strategies for PCIS include acetaminophen, colchicine, and high-dose aspirin (2 to 4 gm daily). In a recent randomized trial, the addition of colchicine to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or aspirin improved outcomes in patients with acute pericarditis. Patients with PCIS should avoid non-aspirin nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and glucocorticoids (which are used for patients with other causes of pericarditis) because they impede myocardial healing.

Given the patient’s recent acute cardiac event and stent placement, she would remain on dual antiplatelet therapy even with the increased aspirin dose (i.e., the second antiplatelet agent would be continued).

Key learning point: Postcardiac injury syndrome (Dressler syndrome) should be treated with high-dose aspirin, analgesics, and colchicine.

D) INCORRECT:

Stent thrombosis is unlikely in this patient, given that her pain, normal serum troponin-T level, and electrocardiographic findings are not consistent with a recurrent anterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction; therefore, repeat cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is not warranted.

E) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary embolism is typically associated with tachycardia and hypoxemia and is a less likely diagnosis than PCIS after a recent myocardial infarction. CT is not warranted.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man reports several hours of left-sided chest and shoulder pain 2 days after receiving a drug-eluting coronary stent for an acute anterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction. His door-to-balloon time was 4 hours. Lying down and taking a deep breath exacerbates his chest pain.
On examination, his temperature is 38.2°C, his heart rate is 90 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. His breath sounds are normal. He has new scratchy systolic and diastolic auscultatory findings at the left lower sternal border.
A 12-lead electrocardiogram reveals anterior Q waves and diffuse ST-segment elevations.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute stent thrombosis is not associated with fever, pleuritic chest pain, or these auscultatory findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Although papillary muscle rupture or ventricular septal rupture can occur within a few days after acute MI, the patient usually experiences acute pulmonary vascular congestion and hemodynamic instability. In addition, these complications produce systolic but not diastolic murmurs.

C) CORRECT:

Pleuritic chest pain, fever, and scratchy systolic and diastolic auscultatory findings (consistent with pericardial rub) that develop 2 days after a myocardial infarction (MI) are most consistent with a diagnosis of post-MI pericarditis.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with pleuritic chest pain, fever, new scratchy systolic and diastolic auscultatory findings, and new ST-segment elevations within a few days after an acute myocardial infarction is pericarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

In-stent restenosis does not occur within days after stent placement.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism might cause pleuritic pain but would not cause a pericardial friction rub or these electrocardiographic abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe retrosternal chest pain.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
She receives sublingual nitroglycerin, and her blood pressure falls from 130/80 mm Hg to 90/60 mm Hg. The lung fields are clear, and no murmurs or gallops are detected. With rapid administration of 1 liter of normal saline, her blood pressure increases to 110/80 mm Hg.
The patient is transferred to the cardiac catheterization laboratory for urgent coronary angiography, as well as Swan-Ganz catheter placement, to assess her hemodynamic parameters.
Which one of the following hemodynamic measures is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient with RV infarction, the central venous pressure (a measure of right atrial pressure) is elevated, whereas the systolic pressures in the more central chambers (i.e., right ventricle and pulmonary artery) are normal.

B) INCORRECT:

The pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (a measure of left atrial pressure) is low or normal.

C) INCORRECT:

In a patient with RV infarction, the central venous pressure (a measure of right atrial pressure) is elevated, whereas the systolic pressures in the more central chambers (i.e., right ventricle and pulmonary artery) are normal.

D) CORRECT:

The electrocardiogram shows an inferior myocardial infarction (MI), which is most often the result of right coronary artery occlusion. If the occlusion occurs in the proximal portion of the vessel, right ventricular (RV) MI may occur. In a patient with an inferior MI, one indicator of concomitant RV involvement is hypotension that is precipitated or exacerbated by administration of nitroglycerin. A right-sided electrocardiogram can help in reaching this diagnosis; ST-segment elevation in lead V4R is the single most powerful predictor of right ventricular involvement.

In a patient with RV infarction, the central venous pressure (a measure of right atrial pressure) is elevated, whereas the systolic pressures in the more central chambers (i.e., right ventricle and pulmonary artery) are normal.

Key learning point: The hemodynamic variable that is most likely to be elevated in a patient with a right ventricular infarction is central venous pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac output is normal or reduced, not increased, in the setting of MI. Despite the elevation in central venous pressure, patients with RV infarction are quite preload-dependent; thus, in the setting of hypotension, they often require substantial expansion of intravascular volume (with intravenous fluid administration).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with hypertension presents to the emergency department with epigastric pain, nausea, and diaphoresis. His symptoms started one week ago and initially lasted for 5 to 10 minutes before resolving spontaneously. The current episode started just after lunch (2 hours ago), and his pain has not yet subsided. His home medications are lisinopril and amlodipine.
The patient has a heart rate of 62 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and his extremities are well perfused.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiogram (ECG) and clinical presentation are consistent with an inferoposterior myocardial infarction (MI). The patient’s ECG shows ST-segment depression in leads V1 to V3 with a tall R wave in leads V2 and V3. This finding represents an acute infarction of the posterior wall; often, there is also a dominant R wave in V1, which was not seen here. This patient’s ECG also shows subtle ST-segment changes in leads III and aVF, which is also suggestive of an inferior MI. Although the patient does not report chest pain, the presence of epigastric pain with nausea and diaphoresis in someone with risk factors for coronary disease should always prompt an investigation for an acute coronary syndrome.

In a true isolated posterior MI (which is rare), there are no inferior or lateral lead changes. The only changes on a standard ECG are ST-segment depressions in the anterior leads (V1 to V3), which are essentially the reciprocal changes of ST elevations in the posterior wall. Abnormally tall R waves in V1 and V2 are also a clue because they are essentially the reciprocal changes of Q waves.

The posterior wall of the left ventricle is not directly represented on a standard 12-lead ECG; in the presence of indirect findings consistent with a posterior or inferoposterior MI, a second tracing, including leads V7, V8, and/or V9, should be obtained. These leads will reveal Q waves or ST-segment elevation.

Key learning point: Electrocardiographic findings of prominent R waves and ST-segment depression in the septal and anterior precordial leads (V1, V2, and/or V3) are consistent with a diagnosis of acute posterior myocardial infarction.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease, esophageal spasm, and aortic dissection may manifest with epigastric pain but would not be expected to produce the ECG features of a posterior MI.

C) INCORRECT:

In this patient, ST-segment depression should not be interpreted as a sign of subendocardial ischemia, as it represents mirrored findings of a posterior ST-segment elevation MI. The subtle ST-segment elevation in the inferior (II, III and aVF) leads makes this an acute inferoposterior MI. An inappropriate diagnosis of unstable angina would be likely to delay definitive reperfusion treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease, esophageal spasm, and aortic dissection may manifest with epigastric pain but would not be expected to produce the ECG features of a posterior MI.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease, esophageal spasm, and aortic dissection may manifest with epigastric pain but would not be expected to produce the ECG features of a posterior MI.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man with a history of cigarette smoking presents with retrosternal chest pain that spontaneously resolved before his arrival in the emergency department. Shortly after arrival, the patient reports lightheadedness and worsening chest pressure.
His heart rate is 54 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 88/40 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 100% while he receives high-flow supplemental oxygen. His jugular venous pressure is measured at 8 cm of water. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs or additional heart sounds. The lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion.
An electrocardiogram reveals ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, with elevation in the ST segment in lead V4 on the right side.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A right ventricular (RV) infarction should be considered in all patients who present with an acute inferior-wall myocardial infarction (MI), especially in the setting of hypotension. The classic clinical triad of RV infarction includes hypotension, distended neck veins, and clear lungs in the setting of an inferior MI.

All patients with an inferior MI should have a right-sided electrocardiogram. ST-segment elevation in right-sided lead V4 is the most sensitive electrocardiographic indicator of RV infarction. It is important to recognize RV infarction, as it is associated with a higher rate of hypotension, bradycardia requiring pacing support, and in-hospital mortality than is isolated inferior infarction.

Volume loading with intravenous normal saline is first-line therapy for RV infarction complicated by hypotension; it increases RV filling pressures, systolic arterial pressure, and cardiac output.

Key learning point: The most sensitive electrocardiographic indicator for the presence of a right ventricular infarction is ST-segment elevation in lead V4 on the right side.

B) INCORRECT:

Given that patients with an RV infarction are preload-dependent, vasodilators, such as nitrates, are not recommended because they exacerbate hypotension.

C) INCORRECT:

Norepinephrine is inappropriate for a patient with an inferior MI, as the drug increases left ventricular afterload.

D) INCORRECT:

Inotropic therapy with dopamine, or sometimes dobutamine, is indicated when cardiogenic shock is present despite reasonable fluid resuscitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bradycardia, as seen in this patient, and high-degree atrioventricular block are contraindications to beta-blocker use in the setting of MI.

questions.text:
Three days after hospitalization for an acute inferior myocardial infarction, a 67-year-old woman requires intubation and vasopressor support for acute pulmonary edema and hypotension.
Her current heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and she has a holosystolic murmur. A balloon-tipped pulmonary arterial (Swan-Ganz) catheter is placed in the pulmonary artery; it reveals a cardiac index of 1.5 liters/min/m2 (reference range, 2.5–4.0) and the following other information:


Location
Pressure (in mm Hg)
Oxygen Saturation


Right atrium

5 [mean\] (reference range, 2–6)
50%


Pulmonary artery
50/20; 30 [systolic/diastolic; mean\] (reference range, 15–25/8–15; mean, 10–20)
52%


Pulmonary capillary wedge

20 [mean\] with V waves to 40 (reference range, 6–12)
95%


Which one of the following causes is most likely to explain the patient’s current clinical status?

choices.text: Free wall rupture, with cardiac tamponade

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal rupture results in left-to-right intracardiac shunting of blood, which causes a harsh systolic murmur, a left parasternal thrill, and a so-called “step-up” (i.e., increase) in oxygen saturation of the pulmonary arterial blood (relative to the right atrial blood). This patient has none of those features.

B) CORRECT:

Cardiogenic shock, which occurs in about 5% to 8% of patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI), is associated with high rates of morbidity and mortality. Mechanical causes of post-AMI cardiogenic shock are pump failure, acute mitral regurgitation (MR) caused by papillary muscle rupture, ventricular septal rupture, and free wall rupture. A papillary muscle rupture is the mechanical complication most likely to cause cardiogenic shock in a patient who has had an inferior myocardial infarction and has no evidence of intracardiac shunting. This patient has a normal right atrial pressure and elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (with large V waves), which are consistent with papillary muscle rupture and resultant severe mitral regurgitation.

Papillary muscle rupture typically occurs 3 to 7 days after an inferior infarction; clinical manifestations usually include a new systolic murmur and pulmonary edema. However, with complete papillary muscle rupture and resultant severe valvular regurgitation, the murmur may be faint or even inaudible. Right heart catheterization reveals large V waves in the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) recording, but a large V wave alone is not diagnostic of papillary muscle rupture, as ventricular septal rupture may also be associated with a large V wave.

Key learning point: The mechanical complication of an inferior myocardial infarction that is most likely to cause cardiogenic shock is papillary muscle rupture.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary edema, elevated PCWP, and large PCWP V waves are not characteristic of pulmonary embolism.

D) INCORRECT:

Pump failure typically occurs in the setting of a large anterior myocardial infarction. A normal right atrial pressure would not be expected with pump failure, nor would large V waves on the PCWP tracing.

E) INCORRECT:

Right atrial pressure is markedly elevated in patients with cardiac tamponade, and they have no evidence of pulmonary edema or large V waves on their PCWP tracings.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with a one-hour history of waxing and waning pressure-like pain perceived diffusely in his neck. The pain, which began when he was exercising on a stationary bike, is accompanied by diaphoresis and mild shortness of breath. The pain diminished when he stopped exercising, increased when he walked to his car, and again diminished (but did not resolve) on his way to the hospital. He recently purchased a new mattress and pillow, and he wonders whether he strained his neck while sleeping.
The patient has a blood pressure of 145/82 mm Hg and a heart rate of 94 beats per minute. Neurologic examination reveals 5/5 strength in the upper and lower extremities on both sides, as well as intact cranial nerves II through XII. The neck is not tender to palpation.
His troponin-T level, measured using a 4th-generation assay, is 0.01 ng/mL (reference range, 0–0.03). An electrocardiogram shows nonspecific ST-segment and T-wave changes.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recheck the troponin-T level in 6 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A right-sided ECG is indicated in a patient with an inferior myocardial infarction or electrocardiographic suggestions of a right-sided myocardial infarction (e.g., hypotension, ST-segment elevation in lead V1, or ST-segment elevation that is taller in lead III than in lead II). A right-sided ECG is not indicated in a patient with nonspecific ST-segment and T-wave changes.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with diabetes mellitus who are experiencing a myocardial infarction are more likely than other patients to present without chest pain. Health care providers should be alert for nonclassic symptoms such as jaw, neck, ear, arm, or epigastric discomfort, which can be “anginal equivalents.” New-onset exertional dyspnea is the most common anginal equivalent.

Given this patient’s persistent neck pain and a high clinical suspicion for angina, administration of oxygen, aspirin, and nitroglycerin are the most appropriate next steps for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. The absence of overt changes on electrocardiogram (ECG) does not rule out an acute coronary syndrome. The troponin-T level may initially be normal in patients with an acute coronary syndrome, but then it becomes elevated a few hours after the onset of symptoms.

Key learning point: A nonclassic presentation of an acute coronary syndrome is most common among patients with a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications might be appropriate for a patient with cervical strain, but that diagnosis should not be considered while myocardial ischemia is being addressed.

D) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the carotid artery would be appropriate if carotid dissection was a stronger consideration. However, carotid dissection usually manifests with neck pain and headache ipsilateral to the dissection, as well as focal neurologic symptoms and signs.

E) INCORRECT:

There is some urgency in managing an acute coronary syndrome, so simply observing the patient (i.e., delaying aspirin and nitroglycerin) and waiting 6 hours to measure troponin levels is not an optimal management strategy. Troponin levels should be rechecked much sooner, typically 2 to 3 hours after the initial troponin level but sometimes even sooner depending on the clinical presentation and troponin assay used.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old male former smoker is evaluated as an outpatient. One week ago, he underwent drug-eluting stent placement in his left anterior descending coronary artery after he presented with a non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 52%. His current medications are dual therapy with aspirin and ticagrelor, rosuvastatin, atenolol, and losartan.
He is currently symptom-free. Physical examination reveals a heart rate of 62 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 116/68 mm Hg.
Laboratory evaluation reveals normal hemoglobin, normal creatinine, an LDL-cholesterol concentration of 67 mg/dL (reference range, <130), and a glycated hemoglobin concentration of 5.7% (4.3–5.6).
Which one of the following additional treatments is indicated to lower mortality risk for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone is not indicated in a patient whose left ventricular ejection fraction is >40% and who had no heart failure during the index hospitalization.

B) CORRECT:

Cardiac rehabilitation is associated with reduced mortality risk in patients with a recent myocardial infarction, those who have undergone coronary revascularization, and those with chronic stable angina. In addition, cardiac rehabilitation can improve exercise tolerance and coronary risk factors, such as lipid levels and blood pressure.

This patient is currently on an appropriate pharmacologic regimen for his coronary artery disease.

Key learning point: In addition to drug treatment, a patient with a recent myocardial infarction should be referred for cardiac rehabilitation, as it is associated with reduced risks for all-cause and cardiovascular mortality.

C) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine is not indicated in a patient whose blood pressure is well controlled on other antihypertensive therapies. In addition, investigations into the use of calcium-channel blockers to prevent stent restenosis have been inconclusive.

D) INCORRECT:

Metformin has no proven mortality benefit in patients with prediabetes.

E) INCORRECT:

Isosorbide dinitrate is not indicated in a patient without angina.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man returns 4 months after an anterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, for which he underwent drug-eluting stent placement in an occluded left anterior descending artery. His predischarge left ventricular ejection fraction was 52%. He currently takes aspirin, prasugrel, pravastatin, losartan, and carvedilol.
He walks on a treadmill for 30 minutes four times a week with no chest pain. He occasionally experiences burning in his chest after eating a particularly heavy or spicy meal, a symptom that he has experienced for many years.
His electrocardiogram shows a previous anteroseptal myocardial infarction.
In addition to monitoring blood pressure, lipid concentrations, and other cardiovascular risk factors, which one of the following approaches to follow-up evaluation is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: A repeat coronary angiogram before discontinuing prasugrel
An exercise treadmill test in 8 months
No additional evaluation, unless the patient develops new cardiac symptoms

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient who underwent drug-eluting stent placement for ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction, a P2Y12 inhibitor such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel should be taken for at least 12 months after stent placement and then can be discontinued; a repeat coronary angiogram is not necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of burning in the chest or other postprandial symptoms of dyspepsia that preceded the diagnosis of coronary artery disease are not typical of angina, so cardiac stress testing is not warranted in this patient. Cardiac stress testing after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is appropriate in a patient whose symptoms suggest incomplete revascularization or restenosis. Routine exercise treadmill testing after PCI is not recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine exercise treadmill testing after PCI is not recommended.

D) CORRECT:

The recommended cardiac follow-up evaluation for an asymptomatic patient in the year after placement of a drug-eluting stent is monitoring of medication adherence, blood pressure, and lipid concentrations, as well as management of other cardiovascular risk factors.

Key learning point: The recommended cardiac follow-up evaluation for an asymptomatic patient in the year after placement of a drug-eluting stent is monitoring of medication adherence, blood pressure, lipid concentrations, as well as management of other cardiovascular risk factors. Routine stress testing is not recommended for asymptomatic patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Although of unclear clinical utility, cardiac imaging can be considered in an asymptomatic patient 3 years after PCI or 5 years after coronary artery bypass grafting.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for 4 hours of anterior chest discomfort that developed after he was moving furniture and then resolved. He describes the pain as a pressure in the front of his chest, with radiation to the left shoulder.
He began intermittent hemodialysis 6 months ago for end-stage kidney disease attributed to hypertensive nephrosclerosis. He notes lower-extremity edema that resolves after dialysis but is otherwise asymptomatic. He has had hypertension for more than 30 years and also has hyperlipidemia. His current medications are aspirin, metoprolol, simvastatin, losartan, calcium acetate, and erythropoietin.
On examination, his blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 65 beats per minute. At rest, he appears to be comfortable and without pain. The pain is reproduced when he rotates his body and upon palpation of his anterior chest on the left side. He has a normal cardiac examination and clear lung fields. Bilateral trace edema is present.
An electrocardiogram indicates left ventricular hypertrophy with repolarization abnormality, consistent with previous electrocardiographic results.
Laboratory testing, conducted before dialysis, reveals a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL (reference range, 13.5–17.5) and a potassium level of 5.0 mEq/liter (3.5–5.0). A cardiac troponin-T level, obtained in the emergency department upon arrival using a 4th-generation assay, is 0.2 ng/mL (0–0.03).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Await a second cardiac troponin-T level for comparison at 4 hours after presentation
Discharge home with outpatient follow-up scheduled within 3 days
Add ticagrelor to the current regimen
Refer for immediate cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the general population, an elevated serum cardiac troponin-T (cTnT) level is an indicator of subclinical myonecrosis and a predictor of cardiovascular and all-cause mortality independent of other cardiovascular risk factors. In patients with end-stage kidney disease, however, this marker has variable specificity: these patients often have elevated cTnT levels but no clinical evidence of acute myocardial injury. In this particular case, the patient has end-stage kidney disease and is reporting chest pain that requires further evaluation. Although no changes are seen on electrocardiogram, there is concern for cardiac ischemia given the patient's end-stage kidney disease (a known risk for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality), his reported chest pain, and his mild cTnT elevation. The most appropriate next step for this patient is to repeat the cTnT level. If the second cTnT level is higher than the first, the cause is likely cardiac, and management should be focused accordingly. If there is no change in the cTnT level, the elevation is likely due to end-stage kidney disease, and the patient's medical therapy can be continued without modification.

Key learning point: In a patient with end-stage kidney disease who undergoes intermittent dialysis, an elevated serum cardiac troponin-T level is associated with increased risk for cardiovascular disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharge home with outpatient follow-up would be reasonable if the patient’s symptoms resolved and a second cardiac troponin-T level was unchanged, but it would be premature at this point given that an acute cardiac syndrome has not been adequately ruled out.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress testing is not indicated at this time until there is determination of a follow-up cardiac troponin-T level.

D) INCORRECT:

Ticagrelor is unlikely to lower the serum cardiac troponin-T level or to reduce the risk for cardiovascular mortality on dialysis.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no indication for immediate cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography, as the electrocardiogram does not demonstrate ST-segment elevation.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain and extreme anxiety one hour after his most recent use of cocaine. His symptoms have been progressing, and during the past 30 minutes, he has experienced a pressure in the center of his chest as well as jaw pain. He reports that his heart is racing and he feels short of breath. He has no known medical problems or allergies.
He has a temperature of 37.2°C, a heart rate of 96 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 160/100 mm Hg. His electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in contiguous leads.
In addition to aspirin, which one of the following combinations of medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Using beta-blockers to treat cocaine-related cardiotoxicity is controversial, and studies over the years have demonstrated both benefit and harm associated with using this class of medication in such cases. There is concern that beta-blockade will result in unopposed alpha-adrenergic effects, with exacerbation of coronary vasoconstriction.

B) CORRECT:

Chest pain is one of the most common cocaine-related medical problems. Within hours of cocaine use, the patient is at high risk for cardiac events. A patient with chest pain and ischemic electrocardiographic changes after use of cocaine should be treated with aspirin, lorazepam, and nitroglycerin. Aspirin is indicated because cocaine enhances platelet aggregation; lorazepam helps to reduce anxiety; and nitroglycerin reverses cocaine-induced coronary arterial vasoconstriction.

Key learning point: First-line treatment for cocaine-induced myocardial infarction involves aspirin, lorazepam, and nitroglycerin. Expert consensus does not support the use of beta-blockers in this setting.

C) INCORRECT:

Using beta-blockers to treat cocaine-related cardiotoxicity is controversial, and studies over the years have demonstrated both benefit and harm associated with using this class of medication in such cases. There is concern that beta-blockade will result in unopposed alpha-adrenergic effects, with exacerbation of coronary vasoconstriction. However, after acute intoxication has subsided and cocaine has been eliminated, a beta-blocker may be started if acute coronary syndrome is confirmed and there are no other contraindications to beta-blockade.

D) INCORRECT:

Phentolamine can help to mitigate cocaine-induced vasoconstriction, but it requires intravenous administration and may exacerbate tachycardia. Thus, it should be used only if symptoms are resistant to initial treatment with nitroglycerin, lorazepam, and aspirin.

E) INCORRECT:

Using beta-blockers to treat cocaine-related cardiotoxicity is controversial, and studies over the years have demonstrated both benefit and harm associated with using this class of medication in such cases. There is concern that beta-blockade will result in unopposed alpha-adrenergic effects, with exacerbation of coronary vasoconstriction. Phentolamine can help to mitigate cocaine-induced vasoconstriction, but it requires intravenous administration and may exacerbate tachycardia. Thus, it should be used only if symptoms are resistant to initial treatment with nitroglycerin, lorazepam, and aspirin.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is hospitalized with an uncomplicated inferior myocardial infarction. On the second hospital day, a midsystolic murmur is heard at the apex. The murmur extends to the second heart sound but is neither harsh nor scratchy; it had not been present on admission. The patient has been clinically stable: He has no symptoms or signs of heart failure, no recurrent chest pain, and no arrhythmias.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s systolic murmur?

choices.text: Left ventricular and mitral annulus dilatation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rupture of a papillary muscle and rupture of the interventricular septum are rare but serious complications of acute myocardial infarction. These complications generally cause pulmonary edema and hypotension, which are not present in this case. The systolic murmur associated with papillary muscle rupture is variable in duration.

B) INCORRECT:

With septal rupture, the resulting ventricular septal defect and left-to-right shunting cause a holosystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border.

C) INCORRECT:

A common cause of holosystolic MR is dilatation of the left ventricle in the setting of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. This patient has no signs or symptoms of heart failure, and his murmur is not holosystolic.

D) INCORRECT:

Pericarditis can also complicate myocardial infarction. Pericardial rubs, which often have more than one component, usually sound scratchy.

E) CORRECT:

A murmur of mitral regurgitation (MR) can be holosystolic (beginning immediately with the first heart sound), or its onset can be delayed after the first heart sound, as in this case. Papillary muscle displacement (formerly called "papillary muscle dysfunction"), resulting from coronary ischemia involving the adjacent ventricular wall, can cause a mid-to-late systolic MR murmur. Mitral valve prolapse is another common cause of a midsystolic MR murmur.

Key learning point: A new mid-to-late systolic murmur that develops after an acute inferior myocardial infarction in a patient who is clinically stable without features of heart failure is most likely caused by papillary muscle displacement.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old former smoker with a history of hypertension presents for follow-up one week after a recent hospitalization for chest pain. He was diagnosed with an ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction with occlusion of the left anterior descending artery on cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography, and two drug-eluting stents were placed. After the procedure, he developed acute kidney injury, thought to be secondary to contrast-induced nephropathy, with a serum creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3).
A transthoracic echocardiogram performed before discharge showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% with significant anterior-wall hypokinesis. The patient was discharged on aspirin, clopidogrel, rosuvastatin, and metoprolol succinate.
Today he has a blood pressure of 113/70 mm Hg, a heart rate of 78 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 94% while breathing ambient air. He has normal heart sounds, no murmurs, and mild lower-extremity edema. He has mild dyspnea with ordinary physical activity but no orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and his weight has been stable since discharge.
Laboratory testing reveals a serum creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3) and a potassium level of 4.2 mEq/liter (3.5–5.0).
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for improving the likelihood of survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide and digoxin may improve symptoms in patients with reduced LV fraction, but there is no evidence to support a survival benefit.

B) INCORRECT:

The calcium-channel blocker (CCB) amlodipine is safe to use in patients with LV dysfunction but does not confer a survival benefit. No reduction in mortality has been seen for other CCBs in this population either, and studies of diltiazem have raised concerns about harm.

C) INCORRECT:

Furosemide and digoxin may improve symptoms in patients with reduced LV fraction, but there is no evidence to support a survival benefit.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of hydralazine and a nitrate has been shown to improve the likelihood of survival in Black patients with New York Heart Association class III to IV heart-failure symptoms. Current guidelines therefore recommend using this combination as an additional therapy in Black patients who are symptomatic despite standard therapy with ACE inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARBs) — or as an alternative therapy in patients of any race or ethnicity who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors or ARBs. The combination is not appropriate for this patient (regardless of his race or ethnicity), because he has not yet received an ACE inhibitor.

E) CORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are a cornerstone of treatment for patients who have depressed left ventricular (LV) systolic function (i.e., ejection fraction ≤40%) after a myocardial infarction (MI), even if they do not have overt symptoms of heart failure. In a large trial of patients with asymptomatic LV dysfunction after MI, there was a 19% relative risk reduction in all-cause mortality among those who received the ACE inhibitor captopril compared with those who received placebo. Notably, more than half the patients in this trial did not have a history of hypertension, suggesting that ACE inhibitors confer a survival benefit even in patients with normal blood pressure.

Mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonists (spironolactone and eplerenone) represent another drug class that reduces mortality in patients who have heart failure and LV ejection fraction ≤35%. It would be appropriate to add one of these agents in this case, in addition to the ACE inhibitor.

Key learning point: The most appropriate medication to initiate in a patient who has depressed left ventricular systolic function after a myocardial infarction and who already takes dual antiplatelet therapy and a beta-blocker is an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with a history of cigarette smoking presents with retrosternal chest pain that spontaneously resolved before his arrival in the emergency department. Shortly after arrival, the patient reports lightheadedness and worsening chest pressure. His heart rate is 54 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 88/40 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 100% while he receives high-flow supplemental oxygen. His jugular venous pressure is measured at 8 cm of water. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs or additional heart sounds. The lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. An electrocardiogram reveals ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, with elevation in the ST segment in lead V4 on the right side. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A right ventricular (RV) infarction should be considered in all patients who present with an acute inferior-wall myocardial infarction (MI), especially in the setting of hypotension. The classic clinical triad of RV infarction includes hypotension, distended neck veins, and clear lungs in the setting of an inferior MI.

All patients with an inferior MI should have a right-sided electrocardiogram. ST-segment elevation in right-sided lead V4 is the most sensitive electrocardiographic indicator of RV infarction. It is important to recognize RV infarction, as it is associated with a higher rate of hypotension, bradycardia requiring pacing support, and in-hospital mortality than is isolated inferior infarction.

Volume loading with intravenous normal saline is first-line therapy for RV infarction complicated by hypotension; it increases RV filling pressures, systolic arterial pressure, and cardiac output.

Key learning point: The most sensitive electrocardiographic indicator for the presence of a right ventricular infarction is ST-segment elevation in lead V4 on the right side.

B) INCORRECT:

Given that patients with an RV infarction are preload-dependent, vasodilators, such as nitrates, are not recommended because they exacerbate hypotension.

C) INCORRECT:

Norepinephrine is inappropriate for a patient with an inferior MI, as the drug increases left ventricular afterload.

D) INCORRECT:

Inotropic therapy with dopamine, or sometimes dobutamine, is indicated when cardiogenic shock is present despite reasonable fluid resuscitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bradycardia, as seen in this patient, and high-degree atrioventricular block are contraindications to beta-blocker use in the setting of MI.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office because of nausea and shortness of breath that started 1 hour ago. He also reports lightheadedness that started earlier in the day. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin and sitagliptin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He appears pale and diaphoretic. 12-lead electrocardiography is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An acute posterior myocardial infarction (MI) can be diagnosed based on the presence of ST elevations on special leads V7–V9. On a standard 12-lead ECG, a posterior MI manifests with reciprocal ST depression in leads V1–V4 or an R:S wave ratio > 1 in leads V1 and V2 due to an increase in the R wave amplitude. This patient only has an ST depression in lead V2 and an R:S ratio < 1 in leads V1 and V2. It is therefore unlikely that this patient has had a posterior wall MI.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ~ 83/min
– Sinus rhythm
– Normal axis (R > S in I and II)
– Downsloping ST depression in leads V2 and V3 and horizontal ST depression in V4 (examples indicated by red overlay) is accompanied by positive T waves (examples indicated by blue overlay). This appearance is reciprocal to posterior ST elevations with T-wave inversions.
– Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2 (example indicated by green overlay): reciprocal to posterior Q waves
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): rSR′ complex in V1 and QRS duration of 0.12 s

These findings suggest a posterior myocardial infarction. To confirm, an additional ECG including the posterior leads V7–V9 can be obtained to look for ST elevation, T-wave inversion, and Q waves. Note that ST depression ≥ 0.5 mm in leads V1–V4 is a STEMI-equivalent ECG finding (i.e., management is the same as that for STEMI).

B) INCORRECT:

Acute pericarditis can cause shortness of breath and ST elevations on ECG. However, the ST elevations in pericarditis typically occur diffusely in all leads, in contrast to this patient's ECG findings. Moreover, clinical features such as fever, a pericardial friction rub, and/or retrosternal chest pain are expected in a patient with acute pericarditis.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

Sinus tachycardia with a frequency of approx. 107/min.
Normal heart axis (R > S in both I and aVF).
P waves have normal morphology. Diffuse PR depressions with reciprocal, concave ST elevations (best seen in aVL) and PR elevations in aVR. Note the notching at the end of the QRS complexes (creating the “fish hook” morphology; best seen in aVL). Discordant T wave in V1.
PR interval normal (approx. 120 ms), QRS interval borderline narrow (approx. 80 ms), QT interval prolonged (approx. 400 ms; QTc = 534 ms).

These findings are typical for stage 1 in acute pericarditis.

C) CORRECT:

Acute inferior myocardial infarction (MI) is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with dyspnea, lightheadedness, ST elevation in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF), and reciprocal ST depression in leads I and aVL. This patient has significant risk factors for atherosclerotic disease, including type 2 diabetes mellitus and a 20 pack-year smoking history. Acute STEMI is usually diagnosed based on the initial ECG and the presence of typical ischemic chest pain. However, diabetic patients and elderly women may have an atypical presentation with little or no chest pain and predominantly autonomic symptoms (e.g., nausea).

Key learning point: Acute inferior myocardial infarction is indicated by ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, often with reciprocal ST depression in leads I and aVL.

D) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation can manifest with nausea, shortness of breath, and light-headedness. However, in the case of atrial fibrillation, the ECG shows a variable RR interval and absent P waves. This patient has a constant RR interval and clearly discernible P waves on ECG, making atrial fibrillation unlikely.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm

– Average ventricular rate is ∼ 144/min (24 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

E) INCORRECT:

A saddle pulmonary embolism can manifest with shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and nonspecific ST elevations on ECG. However, this patient is lacking features of right ventricular strain on ECG (e.g., S1Q3T3 pattern, increased R wave amplitude, and ST depression in V1 and V2) and the absence of tachycardia and major risk factors (e.g., prolonged immobilization, recent trauma, surgery, malignancy) make this diagnosis unlikely. This patient's ECG findings are more consistent with a different etiology.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Normal rate (approx. 90/min)
– Cardiac axis ∼ 90° (QRS complex is isoelectric in I and positive in aVF): borderline normal/right-axis deviation
– P pulmonale: P-wave amplitude ≥ 0.25 mV in II, III, and aVF
– PR interval normal (< 0.2 s)
– QRS duration 0.1–0.12 s (incomplete bundle branch block)
– QTc interval normal (∼ 0.4 s)
– Discordant T-wave inversion in III, aVR, V1, V3–V6
– SIQIIITIII-pattern: deep S waves in I (blue overlay), pathological Q waves in III (green overlay), and T-wave inversion in III (red overlay)

The SIQIIITIII-pattern and P pulmonale are both suggestive of pulmonary embolism, but neither of these findings is sensitive or specific for this diagnosis.
questions.hint: The ECG shows ST elevations in II, III, and aVF.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of retrosternal chest pressure and shortness of breath for 4 hours. The symptoms started while he was walking to work and have only minimally improved with rest. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He appears uncomfortable. His pulse is 95/min. Serum studies show a normal troponin concentration. Electrocardiography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Coronary artery occlusion due to transient increase in vascular tone
Infarction and rupture of a papillary muscle
Disruption of an atherosclerotic plaque with a nonocclusive coronary artery thrombus
Atherosclerotic plaque thrombus with complete coronary artery occlusion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve thickening and calcification result in aortic stenosis. This condition typically remains asymptomatic for years, but exertional angina and dyspnea can develop gradually as the aortic valve becomes increasingly stenotic. If the stenosis becomes severe, patients can experience symptoms at rest. Aortic stenosis is not likely to initially manifest with sudden-onset symptoms that do not improve with rest as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery occlusion due to a transient increase in vascular tone is the underlying pathology of vasospastic angina, which causes episodic angina and dyspnea at rest. Though vasospastic angina does not cause increased serum concentrations of cardiac biomarkers such as troponin, it is associated with reversible ST elevations on ECG, which are not seen in this patient. Moreover, episodes of angina caused by this condition typically last for 5–15 minutes. This patient has had 4 hours of progressive symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of myocardial infarction that most commonly develops 2–7 days after infarction and involves the mitral valve, which leads to sudden-onset hypotension and severe mitral regurgitation that can manifest with dyspnea. This complication would not develop in the acute phase of infarction.

D) CORRECT:

Disruption of an atherosclerotic plaque with a nonocclusive coronary artery thrombus can impair coronary artery perfusion and result in myocardial ischemia that causes unstable angina pectoris. This condition includes new-onset angina pectoris and angina pectoris that increases in frequency or severity over time. Symptoms typically persist for ≥ 20 minutes and can occur at rest or with minimal exertion as seen in this case. Unstable angina pectoris does not cause cardiac biomarker elevation. ECG can be normal or show ST depression and/or T-wave inversion.

E) INCORRECT:

An atherosclerotic plaque thrombus with complete coronary artery occlusion results in myocardial infarction (e.g., STEMI, NSTEMI), which manifests with chest pain and dyspnea. However, myocardial infarction causes increased serum concentrations of cardiac biomarkers such as troponin, which are not seen in this patient. Moreover, myocardial infarction is usually associated with characteristic ECG changes (e.g., ST elevation, ST depression).
questions.hint: This patient with multiple cardiovascular risk factors (older age, male sex, history of diabetes mellitus and smoking) has unstable angina pectoris, a condition that can cause chest pain and dyspnea at rest without cardiac biomarker elevation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of acute chest pain. He has hypertension. Current medications include atorvastatin and lisinopril. He appears pale and diaphoretic. His pulse is 114/min and blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg. Electrocardiography shows ST-segment depressions in leads II, III, and aVF. Laboratory studies show an increased serum troponin T concentration. The patient is treated for acute coronary syndrome and undergoes percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty with stent placement. At the time of discharge, echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 58%. In addition to aspirin, which of the following drugs should be added to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) improve mortality and left ventricular ejection fraction after acute coronary syndrome. Initiation of treatment with an ACE inhibitor or ARB is recommended for stable patients within the first 24 hours after the onset of symptoms. However, this patient already receives lisinopril therapy, and combination therapy with both an ACE inhibitor and an ARB is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine therapy is associated with increased mortality after acute myocardial infarction; therefore, it should be avoided in the acute management of coronary artery disease. Nifedipine can be added as an adjunct to beta blockers in patients with stable ischemic heart disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation therapy is indicated in the management of acute coronary syndrome. For patients treated with fibrinolytic therapy, enoxaparin is appropriate; unfractionated heparin or bivalirudin are preferred for patients undergoing PTCA. Anticoagulation is not indicated after discharge from the hospital.

D) CORRECT:

Long-term dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (e.g., clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor) is the recommended regimen for all patients after reperfusion therapy. DAPT reduces mortality and the risk of developing subsequent ischemic episodes and stent thrombosis. The duration of DAPT is an individual decision based on bleeding risk and the risk of stent thrombosis. After PCI with stent placement, DAPT is usually recommended for 12 months. In addition to DAPT, long-term pharmacotherapy for secondary prevention after acute coronary syndrome consists of an ACE inhibitor, beta blocker, nitrate, and high-dose statin therapy. Low-dose aspirin therapy is continued lifelong.

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment with an aldosterone receptor antagonist such as spironolactone is indicated following acute myocardial infarction in patients with left ventricular dysfunction (LVEF ≤ 40%) who develop symptoms of congestive heart failure (e.g., paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, lower extremity edema) or have a history of diabetes mellitus. This patient does not meet the criteria for treatment with spironolactone.
questions.hint: This patient had an acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and underwent percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) with stent placement. His discharge medication regimen should be directed at reducing the risk of subsequent ischemic events and mortality.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe epigastric pain and vomiting that started 30 minutes ago while gardening. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis and jugular venous distention. Electrocardiography shows P waves independent of QRS complexes and ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Coronary angiography is most likely to show narrowing of which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The left coronary artery (LCA) branches to the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and the left circumflex artery (LCX). Occlusion of the LCA can lead to a massive myocardial infarction involving a combination of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), apical (leads I, aVL, V3– V5), and posterolateral (leads II, III, aVF, and V5– V7, and sometimes lead I and aVL) walls. This patient's ECG is consistent with infarction of the inferior wall, which can be supplied by the distal LCX but is more commonly supplied by a different artery.

B) CORRECT:

Occlusion of the proximal right coronary artery (RCA) can cause an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which in turn can present atypically with epigastric pain. High-degree atrioventricular block can occur in this setting because the sinoatrial node (SA node) and atrioventricular node (AV node) are usually supplied by the RCA (the SA node directly, and the AV node via the AV nodal branch). Right-sided leads (V4R, V5R, and V6R) should also be obtained to evaluate for right ventricular (RV) infarction (especially given the patient's jugular venous distention), as the RCA supplies the RV via its right marginal branch.
Image Description:

This image shows the anatomical location of the coronary arteries from a ventral and dorsal view. The left and right coronary arteries arise from the aortic sinus and run along the corresponding coronary sinuses on the caudal side of the heart. The majority of the population has right-dominant coronary artery circulation.

C) INCORRECT:

The left circumflex artery (LCX) supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle. Occlusion of the LCX causes ECG changes in the lateral (V5, V6, I, aVL) leads.
