In patients with left-dominant coronary circulation, occlusion of the LCX causes distal infarction of the posterior descending artery, leading to an inferior wall myocardial infarction and ECG changes in the posterior/posterolateral (V7–V9) and inferior (II, III, aVF) leads. However, the LCX is not the most likely source of this patient's inferior wall myocardial infarction because only approx. 10% of the population is left-dominant.

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) causes infarction of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), and/or apical wall (leads I, aVL, and V3– V5). The inferior wall is not typically supplied by the LAD. Moreover, although an anteroseptal myocardial infarction can sometimes cause serious arrhythmias, such as a high-degree atrioventricular block (the LAD supplies the left and right bundle branches and partially supplies the left anterior and posterior fascicles), conduction abnormalities are more common following an inferior myocardial infarction.

E) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the posterior interventricular artery would cause a posterior wall myocardial infarction, which would manifest as ST segment depression in leads V1 and V2, sometimes with prominent R waves. Posterior leads (V7– V9) would show ST segment elevation. Epigastric pain is not common in posterior wall myocardial infarctions, nor are conduction abnormalities, since the posterior interventricular artery does not supply the conduction system.
questions.hint: Epigastric pain and vomiting, combined with ST segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF are consistent with an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Dissociated P waves and QRS complexes are indicative of third-degree atrioventricular block.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a dry cough and severe chest pain beginning that morning. Two months ago, he was diagnosed with inferior wall myocardial infarction. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while sitting upright and during expiration. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiography shows diffuse ST elevations. Serum studies show a troponin I of 0.2 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade can result from cardiac wall rupture, a complication of myocardial infarction. Cardiac tamponade would result in acute-onset chest pain and tachypnea, as in this patient, and ventricular free wall rupture can also result in increased troponin levels. However, patients with cardiac tamponade would also have features such as dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, and increased jugular venous pressure. On auscultation, muffled heart sounds rather than a pericardial rub would be heard. An ECG would show low voltage complexes, electrical alternans, and, possibly, tall precordial T waves. Moreover, rupture of the cardiac wall typically occurs within 2 weeks after an MI and is more commonly seen in anterior and/or lateral wall infarcts than with inferior wall infarcts.

B) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis has, on rare occasions, been reported after MI. However, it is a late complication that develops months to years after MI. Moreover, it would manifest with edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, hypotension, increased jugular venous pressure, a pericardial knock, the Kussmaul sign, and pulsus paradoxus, none of which are seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Reinfarction, which is an important consideration in any patient with a recent MI, can manifest with acute-onset chest pain, tachypnea, increased troponin levels, and ST elevations. A dry cough (cardiac asthma) may also be present in some patients with MI. However, a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while sitting upright and during expiration would not be expected in reinfarction. Moreover, the ST elevations would be localized to certain leads, in contrast to the diffuse ST elevations in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Early infarct-associated pericarditis can manifest with fever, tachypnea, chest pain, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST-elevation on ECG. However, early infarct-associated pericarditis typically occurs within a few days after MI, whereas this patient's MI occurred 2 months ago.

E) CORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome), a type of postcardiac injury syndrome, usually occurs 2–10 weeks after MI due to immune-complex mediated damage (type III hypersensitivity reaction) in the pericardium. The exact mechanism of immune-complex formation in Dressler syndrome is not completely understood, but the release of neo-antigens from the infarcted myocardium is suspected to play a role. Patients typically present with features of acute pericarditis such as fever, tachypnea, chest pain that is worse during inspiration and relieved by leaning forward, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), a pericardial rub, increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG. Dressler syndrome may also cause pericardial effusion.

Dressler syndrome is treated with NSAIDs, preferably high-dose aspirin.
questions.hint: The timing of this patient's symptoms in relation to his recent myocardial infarction (MI), the high-pitched scratching sound heard on auscultation, and the presence of diffuse ST elevations suggest a particular diagnosis.

questions.text: Seventy-two hours after admission for an acute myocardial infarction, a 48-year-old man develops dyspnea and a productive cough with frothy sputum. Physical examination shows coarse crackles in both lungs and a blowing, holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex. Electrocardiography shows Q waves in the anteroseptal leads. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Rupture of the ventricular free wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome is a type of pericarditis that arises from an autoimmune reaction to exposed myocardial antigens after acute MI. Patients present with dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, this syndrome would manifest 2–10 weeks after an MI rather than 72 hours as seen in this patient. Furthermore, fever is usually present, cardiac auscultation would reveal a pericardial friction rub, and ECG would show ST elevations in all leads.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic root dilation can occur in postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis, which commonly manifests 1–3 days after MI. Patients with aortic root dilation present with features of aortic regurgitation. These patients have diastolic, not systolic, murmurs. Moreover, this patient is missing other symptoms of pericarditis, such as chest pain and a friction rub.

C) CORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture most commonly occurs 2–7 days after acute myocardial infarction and is due to extensive coagulative necrosis and the formation of granulation tissue at the area of infarction. This patient's localization of Q waves in the anteroseptal leads (e.g., V1–V4) suggests an infarction of the left anterior descending artery, which supplies the anterolateral papillary muscle. Acute mitral regurgitation can lead to signs of heart failure, as seen in this patient. The posteromedial papillary muscle is supplied only by the posterior descending artery and is at especially high risk of ischemia due to lack of collateral supply.

Key learning point: Papillary muscle rupture 2–7 days after myocardial infarction can cause acute mitral regurgitation, leading to sudden heart failure with a new holosystolic murmur and pulmonary edema.

D) INCORRECT:

Ventricular wall rupture can occur within 2 weeks of myocardial infarction and typically results in hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade, which can manifest with profound right heart failure, shock, and often death. While free wall rupture and cardiac tamponade can also cause acute pulmonary edema, additional expected findings would include pulsus paradoxus and muffled heart sounds, none of which is observed in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the interventricular septum may occur within the first 2 weeks after MI and typically presents with sudden hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia), dyspnea, and new-onset holosystolic murmur. However, because blood is shunted from left to right, patients typically present with signs of right heart failure (e.g., increased JVP, peripheral edema) rather than the signs of isolated left heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, elevated PCWP) seen here. Moreover, the expected murmur would be heard best over the left sternal border, not the apex.
questions.hint: This patient's new murmur (blowing, holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex) and evidence of heart failure (dyspnea, bilateral crackles, elevated capillary wedge pressure) suggest acute mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Eight months ago, she underwent an emergency cardiac catheterization with stenting for myocardial infarction. At the time of discharge, her heart configuration was normal, end-diastolic volume was 300 mL, and ejection fraction was 51%. For the past 6 weeks, she has noticed increasing shortness of breath on exertion. She has hypertension and coronary artery disease, but admits to rarely taking her medication. Echocardiography shows left ventricular thinning and dilation, an increase in end-diastolic volume, and a decrease in ejection fraction. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's worsening of ventricular function?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is usually added to baseline treatment with furosemide in patients with HF who do not achieve sufficient diuresis with loop diuretics alone. Thiazides are used for symptom relief, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

B) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as enalapril have been found to decrease cardiac remodeling by slowing down the rate of left ventricular thinning and dilation after acute MI. This effect is achieved by decreasing preload and afterload due to blockage of angiotensin II. This patient's presentation with dyspnea on exertion, left ventricular dilation on echocardiogram, and a decrease in ejection fraction is consistent with mild to moderate HF.

Indications for ACE inhibitors (and angiotensin II receptor antagonists) in the secondary prevention of MI include heart failure, left ventricular ejection fraction < 40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, stable chronic kidney disease, and ST-segment elevation MI (especially with anterior location). Beta blockers have also been shown to have anti-remodeling effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Although inotropic agents such as digoxin improve hemodynamic function in patients with HF, it is mainly used for symptom improvement, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

D) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine has been found to worsen symptoms and hemodynamic status in patients with HF and reduced ejection fraction. Although recent studies have shown attenuated cardiac remodeling when nifedipine is used, there are alternative drugs that have been established as first-line therapy for cardiac remodeling prevention.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) such as diltiazem have not been found to improve mortality and/or remodeling in patients with HF secondary to myocardial infarction. CCBs are mainly used for symptomatic treatment.
questions.hint: This woman did not adhere to her medication regimen after a myocardial infarction (MI). She now presents with dyspnea on exertion, reduced ejection fraction, and left ventricular thinning and dilation, which is consistent with heart failure (HF), most likely due to unhindered cardiac remodeling.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination 4 weeks after he was discharged from the hospital following admission and treatment of a myocardial infarction. He reports that he feels well but notices occasional shortness of breath when he moves around his house. He has no chest pain or dizziness. Vital signs are within normal limits. On cardiac examination, an S3 gallop is heard. A grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best over the apex. Electrocardiography shows persistent ST elevations and deep Q waves in leads V1 through V4. Echocardiography shows dyskinesia and outpouching of a region of the left anterior ventricular wall. The patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperacute (flash) pulmonary edema can be caused by acute severe mitral regurgitation due to papillary muscle rupture following an MI. However, papillary muscle rupture usually occurs 2–7 days after MI, and this patient's MI occurred 4 weeks ago. While a ventricular aneurysm, which this patient has, can lead to heart failure and pulmonary edema, the process is usually subacute and does not lead to hyperacute pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute pericardial effusion can develop in patients with antibody-mediated pericarditis (Dressler syndrome), which can occur several weeks after an MI. This patient, however, has no findings suggestive of pericarditis (e.g., pleuritic chest pain, fever, pericardial friction rub on auscultation, diffuse ST elevations). While he is at risk of pericardial effusion due to ventricular aneurysm rupture, this process would develop acutely, not subacutely.

C) CORRECT:

Ventricular aneurysms can develop several weeks to months after MI because of scar tissue formation that leads to thinning and weakening of the ventricular wall. The relative stasis of blood flow within the aneurysmal segment can cause a mural thrombus to form and embolize to distal locations, leading to ischemic events (e.g., stroke, mesenteric ischemia, renal infarction, acute limb ischemia). Other complications of a ventricular aneurysm include heart failure, ventricular arrhythmias, and myocardial rupture, which can lead to cardiac tamponade.

Small or asymptomatic aneurysms can be managed conservatively (e.g., serial imaging to monitor aneurysm size, treatment of heart failure if present). Oral anticoagulation is indicated in all patients with a left ventricular thrombus. Aneurysmectomy is usually reserved for symptomatic patients who do not respond adequately to medical treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Septic embolization may occur as a complication of infective endocarditis if vegetations embolize to other parts of the body. This patient's systolic murmur is consistent with mitral regurgitation, which puts him at risk of developing infective endocarditis. However, he does not have typical features of endocarditis, such as fever or findings of vegetations on echocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

A left-to-right shunt can occur as a result of interventricular septal rupture after an MI. However, interventricular septal rupture commonly develops within 3–5 days of an MI, whereas this patient's MI occurred 4 weeks ago. Moreover, his echocardiogram shows dyskinesia of the left anterior ventricular wall but no interventricular septum motion abnormalities; patients with ventricular septal aneurysms have an increased risk of septal rupture.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG findings of persistent ST elevations in the anterior chest leads along with outpouching of a discrete region within the left anterior ventricular wall suggest a ventricular aneurysm, a late complication of myocardial infarction (MI). In patients with a left ventricular aneurysm, a systolic murmur might be heard as a result of mitral regurgitation due to the distortion of the ventricle's geometry. A third heart sound is also common in patients with ventricular aneurysms.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of severe retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for 30 minutes. Paramedics report that an ECG recorded en route to the hospital showed ST-segment elevation in I, aVL, and the precordial leads. On arrival, the patient is unresponsive to painful stimuli. Examination shows neither respiration nor pulse. Despite appropriate lifesaving measures, he dies 10 minutes later. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ventricular fibrillation is a cardiac arrhythmia in which multiple ectopic foci of electrical activity within the ventricle cause disorganized depolarization and diminished cardiac output. Patients with ventricular fibrillation require rapid defibrillation and CPR, otherwise hemodynamic instability can lead to loss of consciousness and SCD, which is the leading cause of death post-MI. SCD after MI is usually due to ventricular tachyarrhythmias such as ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation.

B) INCORRECT:

Thromboembolism can result from left ventricular aneurysm or new onset atrial fibrillation post-MI and can cause hemorrhagic stroke. However, these complications typically take days to weeks to develop, and stroke is not a common cause of sudden cardiac death in patients with MI.

C) INCORRECT:

MI that affects the interventricular septum has the potential to rupture, creating a left-to-right shunt and right heart failure. While this would also present with shortness of breath, it would usually not occur until 3–5 days after MI.

D) INCORRECT:

In ventricular aneurysm, a portion of the ventricular free wall affected by the MI will outpouch, putting patients at risk for cardiac arrhythmia, heart failure, and cardiac tamponade, all of which can cause sudden cardiac death. However, ventricular aneurysm happens between 2 weeks and several months after MI.

E) INCORRECT:

MI can cause weakness of the ventricular free wall, which makes it prone to rupture under the high pressures of systole. This results in cardiac tamponade and is often fatal. However, ventricular free wall rupture occurs usually within the first 2 weeks of MI, when necrosis has had time to sufficiently weaken the ventricular free wall tissue, not during first hour post-MI.
questions.hint: The patient's chest pain and dyspnea combined with the finding of ST-segment elevation in a proximal left anterior descending distribution on ECG are highly suggestive of myocardial infarction (MI). The patient's subsequent death within an hour of symptom onset is known as sudden cardiac death (SCD).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with acute-onset substernal chest pain lasting 2 hours. One hour after receiving aspirin and sublingual nitroglycerin, jugular venous pressure is elevated. Breath sounds are clear. He reports ongoing chest discomfort (see report).


Heart rate
60/min


Blood pressure
84/58 mm Hg


Electrocardiography: ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide reduces preload by promoting diuresis, useful in pulmonary edema from left ventricular failure. However, the absence of pulmonary congestion and the presence of hypotension and elevated jugular venous pressure suggest right ventricular involvement, where reducing preload would worsen cardiac output.

B) CORRECT:

The patient presents with signs indicative of a right ventricular infarction, often associated with inferior wall myocardial infarctions. ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, along with hypotension, elevated jugular venous pressure, and clear lung fields, suggests right ventricular involvement. The right ventricle becomes preload dependent due to reduced contractility. Administering a 500 mL normal saline bolus increases right ventricular filling, optimizing left ventricular filling and cardiac output, and helps restore hemodynamic stability.

Key learning point: In the setting of an inferior wall myocardial infarction, right ventricular infarction should be suspected if the patient develops hypotension, elevated JVP, and clear lung fields.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin reduces preload, which is detrimental in right ventricular infarction where preload is crucial for maintaining cardiac output. The patient's hypotension and elevated jugular venous pressure, without pulmonary congestion, indicate right ventricular involvement, making nitroglycerin unsuitable.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers reduce myocardial oxygen demand but are contraindicated in hemodynamic instability. The patient's low blood pressure (84/58 mm Hg) and signs of right ventricular involvement necessitate maintaining preload. Beta-blockers decrease heart rate and contractility, potentially worsening hypotension and leading to cardiogenic shock.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presents with 45 minutes of severe left-sided chest pressure radiating to his jaw to the Emergency Department. He has poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and a 30-pack-year smoking history. He appears diaphoretic and restless but denies palpitations or syncope. He is given sublingual nitroglycerin with partial relief. After intravenous access is obtained, he remains hemodynamically stable (see lab result and report).


Heart rate
94/min


Blood pressure
138/82 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
20/min


Oxygen saturation
97% on room air




Test
Result
Normal Values


Troponin I
1.2 mg/L
0 - 0.4 mg/L


ECG: ST-segment elevations in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6, without reciprocal changes
Which coronary artery is most likely occluded in this patient?

choices.text: Diagonal branch of the left anterior descending artery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

ST-segment elevations in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6 indicate lateral wall ischemia, typically supplied by the left circumflex artery. This artery, when occluded, results in characteristic ST elevations in these leads. While the left anterior descending artery supplies the anterior wall and septum, the broad lateral distribution seen here aligns more consistently with left circumflex involvement.

Key learning point: ST-segment elevation in leads I, AVL, V5, and V6 is indicative of a lateral myocardial infarction.

B) INCORRECT:

The right coronary artery supplies the inferior heart, including the right ventricle and conduction system components. Occlusion typically causes ST-segment elevations in inferior leads (II, III, aVF). The ST-segment elevations in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6 indicate lateral wall ischemia, not consistent with right coronary artery occlusion.

C) INCORRECT:

The diagonal branch of the left anterior descending artery supplies part of the lateral wall and can cause ischemia there. However, its occlusion often affects anterior leads as well. The ST-segment elevations in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5, V6) without anterior involvement suggest left circumflex artery involvement rather than the diagonal branch.

D) INCORRECT:

The posterior descending artery supplies the inferior or posterior myocardium, with occlusion causing ST-segment changes in inferior leads (II, III, aVF) or posterior patterns. The ST-segment elevations in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6 indicate lateral wall ischemia, not consistent with posterior descending artery occlusion.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man presents with sudden onset severe shortness of breath to the clinic three days after an inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Chest auscultation reveals prominent crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination reveals a new loud holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex radiating to the axilla (see reports).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg



ECG: Sinus tachycardia without new ST changes
Chest X-ray: Pulmonary edema

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Rupture of the left ventricular free wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the left ventricular free wall leads to hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade, presenting with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distension. It does not typically present with a loud holosystolic murmur. The pulmonary edema and murmur in this patient suggest mitral regurgitation, not free wall rupture.

B) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular aneurysm develops weeks to months after myocardial infarction due to scar formation and remodeling. It does not cause acute symptoms like severe dyspnea, hypotension, or pulmonary edema shortly after infarction. The new holosystolic murmur at the apex is inconsistent with a ventricular aneurysm, which typically does not produce an acute regurgitant murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Interventricular septal rupture occurs 3 to 5 days post-myocardial infarction and produces a holosystolic murmur due to a left-to-right shunt. This murmur is typically best heard at the left sternal border, often with a palpable thrill. The murmur in this patient is best heard at the apex and radiates to the axilla, indicating mitral regurgitation rather than septal rupture.

D) CORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a mechanical complication that typically occurs 2 to 7 days after a myocardial infarction, particularly affecting the posteromedial papillary muscle due to its single coronary artery supply. This rupture leads to acute mitral regurgitation, causing sudden volume overload in the left atrium and pulmonary circulation, manifesting as pulmonary edema and hypotension. The new loud holosystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation, correlating with the mechanical failure of the mitral valve.

Key learning point: Acute mitral regurgitation due to papillary muscle rupture is a mechanical complication of myocardial infarction, characterized by a new loud systolic murmur, pulmonary edema, and hemodynamic instability.

questions.text: A 58-year-old smoker with a BMI of 33 has exertional chest pain. Which intervention best reduces his risk of future myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stress management can modestly influence cardiovascular health by reducing neurohormonal activation and blood pressure. However, it does not directly address primary risk factors like smoking and obesity, which are more significant contributors to myocardial infarction risk in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Limiting alcohol intake is most beneficial for patients with heavy alcohol use, which is not indicated here. The primary risk factors for this patient are smoking and obesity. Moderate alcohol consumption may not significantly increase coronary risk and might even reduce it.

C) CORRECT:

Smoking significantly contributes to ischemic heart disease by causing endothelial dysfunction, increased platelet aggregation, and chronic inflammation, which promote atherosclerosis. Tobacco smoke's pro-oxidative effects lead to low-density lipoprotein oxidation, enhancing plaque formation and destabilization. Smoking cessation rapidly improves endothelial function, reduces systemic inflammation, and decreases the prothrombotic state, mitigating coronary artery disease progression and reducing myocardial infarction risk.

Key learning point: Modifiable risk factors for ischemic heart disease include smoking and BMI, as both can be managed to reduce cardiovascular risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Reducing sodium intake primarily benefits patients with hypertension, which is not mentioned in this patient. The dominant risk factors are smoking and obesity. Sodium reduction does not directly address the pathophysiological mechanisms driven by these factors.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man returns for follow-up in the Outpatient Clinic two weeks after an anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction treated with a drug-eluting stent. He reports occasional exertional dyspnea and mild fatigue. His current medications include aspirin, ticagrelor, a high-intensity statin, and ramipril. Laboratory values are within normal limits (see report).


Heart rate
84/min


Blood pressure
128/78 mm Hg


Echocardiogram: Left ventricular ejection fraction is 38%
Which of the following additional interventions is most likely to reduce long-term mortality in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, manages hypertension and angina but does not reduce mortality in post-myocardial infarction patients with reduced ejection fraction. The patient's current regimen targets neurohormonal activation and ischemic risks, which are crucial for improving long-term outcomes. Amlodipine's vasodilatory effects do not address ventricular remodeling or neurohormonal modulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is used for conditions like atrial fibrillation and venous thromboembolism, not for post-myocardial infarction management with a drug-eluting stent. The patient is on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and ticagrelor) to prevent stent thrombosis. Switching to warfarin would not address the need for antiplatelet therapy and could increase bleeding risk without providing a mortality benefit.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with a history of myocardial infarction and reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF <40%), beta blockers are essential for reducing long-term mortality. Bisoprolol, a beta-1 selective blocker, decreases heart rate and myocardial oxygen demand, reduces arrhythmia risk, and mitigates adverse ventricular remodeling. Clinical trials have demonstrated its survival benefits by counteracting elevated catecholamine levels post-myocardial infarction. Adding bisoprolol to a regimen of antiplatelet therapy, ACE inhibitors, and high-intensity statins aligns with comprehensive cardiovascular risk reduction strategies in patients with systolic dysfunction following myocardial infarction.

Key learning point: In post-myocardial infarction patients, beta-blockers like bisoprolol are recommended to reduce mortality, decrease the risk of recurrent myocardial infarction, and manage heart failure symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Sublingual nitroglycerin provides rapid relief from angina by causing vasodilation and reducing myocardial oxygen demand. However, it does not modify the structural or neurohormonal changes that affect long-term mortality in post-myocardial infarction patients. Its role is limited to symptomatic relief rather than influencing the progression of heart failure or ventricular remodeling.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man presents with 30 minutes of severe, central, pressure-like chest pain radiating to his jaw. He has a 20-year history of hypertension and recalls experiencing transient episodes of similar chest tightness over the past few months, each lasting only a few seconds. He denies shortness of breath, cough, or pleuritic pain. The rest of the physical examination is normal.


Heart rate
92/min


Blood pressure
152/88 mm Hg


Which of the following is the most likely cause of his current presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic dissection typically presents with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, often with differential blood pressures in the arms or new diastolic murmurs. The patient's pressure-like chest pain radiating to the jaw, without tearing quality or back pain, and his history of transient chest tightness suggest ischemia rather than dissection.

B) CORRECT:

The patient presents with severe, central, pressure-like chest pain radiating to the jaw, indicative of myocardial infarction. This pain, lasting 30 minutes, suggests sustained cardiac ischemia due to coronary artery occlusion, unlike transient angina. His history of hypertension and brief chest tightness episodes points to underlying coronary artery disease, now progressing to an acute event. Myocardial infarction involves atherosclerotic plaque rupture and thrombus formation, leading to myocardial injury. Recognizing these clinical features and risk factors is essential for timely diagnosis and management.

Key learning point: Severe central chest pain with a history of similar fleeting pains suggests myocardial infarction, especially in the absence of other symptoms like shortness of breath or pleuritic pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Pericarditis typically presents with sharp, pleuritic chest pain that worsens with inspiration and improves by sitting up. The patient's pressure-like chest pain radiating to the jaw aligns more with myocardial ischemia. Pericarditis often has a pericardial friction rub or diffuse ST-segment elevations, which are not mentioned here.

D) INCORRECT:

Costochondritis causes localized anterior chest wall pain, reproducible on palpation and worsened by movement or deep inspiration. The patient's prolonged, pressure-like chest pain radiating to the jaw, combined with hypertension and transient chest discomfort, suggests myocardial ischemia rather than a musculoskeletal condition.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man presents two weeks after an ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Which measure best reduces his future cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Smoking cessation is crucial in reducing cardiovascular risk, particularly after a myocardial infarction. Smoking contributes to coronary artery disease by promoting inflammation, endothelial dysfunction, and thrombosis. Quitting smoking improves endothelial function, reduces platelet aggregation, and decreases sympathetic stimulation, thereby lowering the risk of recurrent ischemic events and arrhythmias. It also reduces systemic inflammation, enhancing overall survival and decreasing the likelihood of future cardiovascular events.

Key learning point: Smoking cessation is the most effective preventive measure to improve prognosis after a myocardial infarction, as it significantly reduces the risk of recurrent cardiovascular events and mortality.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antiarrhythmic therapy post-myocardial infarction does not improve survival and may increase mortality due to proarrhythmic effects. Evidence-based strategies focus on lifestyle modifications and medications like beta blockers and statins for long-term benefits.

C) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors reduce gastric acid secretion and are used to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding in patients on antiplatelet therapy. They do not modify cardiovascular risk factors or reduce the risk of recurrent myocardial infarction.

D) INCORRECT:

Omega-3 fatty acids in fish oil have anti-inflammatory and triglyceride-lowering effects, but large trials have not consistently shown significant reductions in cardiovascular events. Established treatments targeting major modifiable risk factors are more effective in reducing cardiovascular risk post-myocardial infarction.

questions.text: You are caring for a 70-year-old man who, three days after cardiac catheterization and coronary angioplasty for acute myocardial infarction, develops shortness of breath at rest. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, sublingual nitroglycerin, metoprolol, and insulin. He is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/55 mm Hg. On examination, crackles are heard at both lung bases. Cardiac examination reveals a new grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. ECG shows sinus rhythm with T wave inversion in leads II, III, and aVF. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture, a life-threatening early complication of myocardial infarction (MI), typically develops within 2–7 days of MI and may cause acute MR. In addition to clinical features of acute left-sided HF and a systolic murmur, findings may also include a midsystolic click due to mitral valve prolapse. ECG findings are unspecific and may show T-wave inversion as a sign of previous and/or current cardiac ischemia. Papillary muscle rupture is more common in patients with involvement of the right coronary, which supplies the posteromedial papillary muscle through the posterior descending artery without any collateral blood supply. The diagnosis can be confirmed using echocardiography, which often shows flailing of a valve segment. The treatment of choice is surgical repair.

See “Overview of MI complications” table.

Key learning point: Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication occurring 2–7 days after myocardial infarction, leading to acute mitral regurgitation, new holosystolic murmur at the apex, and acute left-sided heart failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal rupture usually occurs within 3–5 days after myocardial infarction and typically manifests with de novo HF and a new-onset holosystolic murmur. However, this condition does not cause MR, and the murmur would be heard best over the left sternal border rather than the apex. Moreover, patients typically present with features of predominant right-sided HF, such as increased jugular venous pressure and peripheral edema. In addition, an ECG would show new ST-segment changes, a heart block, decreased/absent Q waves, and/or large P waves (due to atrial overload).

C) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular aneurysm can occur after myocardial infarction (MI) and it can manifest with symptoms of HF and even MR (as a result of tethering of the papillary muscles and/or annular dilation). However, ventricular aneurysm is a late complication of MI that appears weeks to months after infarction. In addition, other features are also expected, such as a double apical impulse, persistent ST elevation on ECG, and deep Q waves in the same leads.

D) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome can result in dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, postmyocardial infarction syndrome usually occurs 2–10 weeks after an MI, and other features such as chest pain and/or fever would be present. Moreover, cardiac auscultation would reveal a pericardial friction rub instead of a new-onset holosystolic murmur, and the ECG would typically show ST-segment elevations in all leads.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular free wall rupture, a complication that occurs within 3–14 days of myocardial infarction, would result in features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, hypotension, tachycardia) due to cardiac tamponade. However, a new-onset murmur is not a typical presentation of cardiac tamponade. Instead, muffled heart sounds on auscultation and other features such as new-onset chest pain, increased JVP, and pulsus paradoxus would be expected. The ECG would typically show low voltage ventricular complexes, electrical alternans, new ST-segment changes, and/or tall T waves in the precordial limbs, none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of acute pulmonary edema (dyspnea, tachypnea, bilateral crackles), hemodynamic compromise (decreased blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis), and a new systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex, all of which suggest de novo heart failure (HF) caused by acute mitral regurgitation (MR).

questions.text: You are seeing a 57-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of crushing substernal chest pain at rest. The pain began gradually during an argument with his wife and has become severe. He does not take any medications. He has a 35-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. He is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.1°C, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation on room air is 97%. Cardiac examination reveals an S4 gallop. Lungs are clear to auscultation. An ECG is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?

choices.text: Occlusion of the right coronary artery.
Occlusion of the left circumflex artery.
Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse coronary vasospasm (vasospastic angina or Prinzmetal angina) manifests with transient substernal chest pain with associated ST changes that last approximately 5 to 15 minutes. This patient's chest pain has lasted for more than 2 hours and ECG 2 hours after onset of chest pain shows ST-segment elevations, pointing towards a different underlying cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the proximal right coronary artery causes myocardial infarction (MI) of the inferior wall (which causes ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF) and/or the right ventricle (which causes ST elevation in leads V1 and V3r–6r on a right-sided ECG). MI of the right side of the heart often manifests with severe hypotension due to right ventricular dysfunction. If there is also infarction of the sinoatrial node and/or atrioventricular node, profound bradycardia may also be observed.

C) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the pericardium (i.e., pericarditis) typically manifests with pleuritic chest pain that worsens while laying down and improves when sitting and/or leaning forward. Pericarditis is also associated with low-grade fever, nonproductive cough, shortness of breath, and a pericardial friction rub on cardiac auscultation, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, ECG in a patient with pericarditis would typically show diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression.

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left circumflex artery would cause a lateral wall myocardial infarction. Infarction of the muscle supplied by the left circumflex artery manifests on ECG as ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, and/or V5–V6, which are seen here. However, occlusion of LCX cannot explain the ST-segment elevation seen in leads V1–V4.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's persistent retrosternal chest pain with ST-segment elevation on ECG in leads I, aVL, and V1–V4 are all consistent with an ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) caused by an occlusion of the proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD). Acute occlusion of the proximal LAD leads to infarction of the anterior wall of the left ventricle. Reciprocal ST-segment depressions may be seen in the inferior leads; this patient's ECG shows reciprocal ST-segment depressions in II, III and aVF.

Key learning point: Occlusion of the proximal left anterior descending artery causes ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction with ST elevations in leads V1–V4, indicating anterior wall infarction.
Image Description:

The obtuse marginal artery is also known as the left marginal artery, and the acute marginal artery is also known as the right marginal artery.
questions.hint: Acute substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and an S4 gallop in a male individual with a history of smoking strongly suggest acute coronary syndrome. This diagnosis is confirmed by the patient's ECG findings.

questions.text: You are seeing a 54-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of nausea and retrosternal chest pain. She has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her current medications are atorvastatin, metformin, and lisinopril. She is diaphoretic. Her serum troponin level is 3000 ng/L (≤ 45). She undergoes cardiac catheterization. A photograph of coronary angiography performed prior to percutaneous coronary intervention is provided. An acute myocardial infarction associated with the finding on angiography is most likely to manifest with ST elevations in which one of the following ECG leads?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ST elevations typically develop in leads V7–V9 on ECG as a result of infarcts that involve the posterior descending artery, which supplies the posterior aspect of the heart. This patient's coronary angiography study shows severe occlusion of the LAD, which does not typically affect these leads.

B) INCORRECT:

ST elevations in leads I and aVR are an atypical finding because these leads do not correspond with any specific territory of the heart that is supplied by a single artery. This patient's coronary angiography study shows severe occlusion of the LAD.

C) CORRECT:

ST elevations typically develop in leads V1–V6 on ECG as a result of infarcts that involve the proximal LAD. Leads V1–V2 correspond to the anteroseptal territory; leads V3–V4 correspond to the anteroapical territory; leads V5–V6 correspond to the anterolateral territory. In some cases, ST elevations in the lateral leads (leads I and aVL) can also develop.

Key learning point: ST-segment elevations in leads V1–V6 on ECG indicate an acute myocardial infarction involving the left anterior descending (LAD) artery territory.
Image Description:

The obtuse marginal artery is also known as the left marginal artery, and the acute marginal artery is also known as the right marginal artery.

D) INCORRECT:

ST elevations typically develop in leads II, III, and aVF on ECG as a result of infarcts that involve the right coronary artery, which supplies the inferior aspect of the heart. This patient's coronary angiography study shows severe occlusion of the LAD, which does not typically affect these leads.

E) INCORRECT:

ST elevations in leads V3R–V6R on ECG typically develop as a result of infarcts that involve the right coronary artery and its branches, which supply the inferior aspect of the heart (e.g., right ventricle). This patient's coronary angiography study shows severe occlusion of the proximal LAD, which does not typically affect these leads.
questions.hint: This patient's coronary angiography study shows proximal narrowing of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. This artery perfuses the anterior surface of the heart: two-thirds of the interventricular septum, the anterolateral papillary muscle, and the anterior surface of the left ventricle.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea and shortness of breath that began 1 hour ago. He also reports lightheadedness that started earlier today. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and takes metformin and sitagliptin. He has a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On examination, he is pale and diaphoretic. A 12-lead electrocardiogram is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation can manifest with nausea, shortness of breath, and light-headedness. However, in the case of atrial fibrillation, the ECG shows a variable RR interval and absent P waves. This patient has a constant RR interval and clearly discernible P waves on ECG, making atrial fibrillation unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A saddle pulmonary embolism can manifest with shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and nonspecific ST elevations on ECG. However, this patient is lacking features of right ventricular strain on ECG (e.g., S1Q3T3 pattern, increased R wave amplitude, and ST depression in V1 and V2) and the absence of tachycardia and major risk factors (e.g., prolonged immobilization, recent trauma, surgery, malignancy) make this diagnosis unlikely. This patient's ECG findings are more consistent with a different etiology.

C) CORRECT:

Acute inferior myocardial infarction (MI) is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with dyspnea, lightheadedness, ST elevation in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF), and reciprocal ST depression in leads I and aVL. This patient has significant risk factors for atherosclerotic disease, including type 2 diabetes mellitus and a 20 pack-year smoking history. Acute STEMI is usually diagnosed based on the initial ECG and the presence of typical ischemic chest pain. However, diabetic patients and elderly women may have an atypical presentation with little or no chest pain and predominantly autonomic symptoms (e.g., nausea).

Key learning point: Acute inferior myocardial infarction presents with ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, often with reciprocal ST depression in leads I and aVL, and may have atypical symptoms in diabetic patients.

D) INCORRECT:

An acute posterior myocardial infarction (MI) can be diagnosed based on the presence of ST elevations on special leads V7–V9. On a standard 12-lead ECG, a posterior MI manifests with reciprocal ST depression in leads V1–V4 or an R:S wave ratio > 1 in leads V1 and V2 due to an increase in the R wave amplitude. This patient only has an ST depression in lead V2 and an R:S ratio < 1 in leads V1 and V2. It is therefore unlikely that this patient has had a posterior wall MI.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute pericarditis can cause shortness of breath and ST elevations on ECG. However, the ST elevations in pericarditis typically occur diffusely in all leads, in contrast to this patient's ECG findings. Moreover, clinical features such as fever, a pericardial friction rub, and/or retrosternal chest pain are expected in a patient with acute pericarditis.
questions.hint: The ECG shows ST elevations in II, III, and aVF.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of retrosternal chest pressure and shortness of breath. The symptoms began while he was walking to work and have only minimally improved with rest. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He appears uncomfortable. His pulse is 95/min. Serum troponin concentration is normal. Electrocardiography is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Infarction and rupture of a papillary muscle.
Coronary artery occlusion due to transient increase in vascular tone.
Disruption of an atherosclerotic plaque with a nonocclusive coronary artery thrombus.
Atherosclerotic plaque thrombus with complete coronary artery occlusion.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of myocardial infarction that most commonly develops 2–7 days after infarction and involves the mitral valve, which leads to sudden-onset hypotension and severe mitral regurgitation that can manifest with dyspnea. This complication would not develop in the acute phase of infarction.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery occlusion due to a transient increase in vascular tone is the underlying pathology of vasospastic angina, which causes episodic angina and dyspnea at rest. Though vasospastic angina does not cause increased serum concentrations of cardiac biomarkers such as troponin, it is associated with reversible ST elevations on ECG, which are not seen in this patient. Moreover, episodes of angina caused by this condition typically last for 5–15 minutes. This patient has had 4 hours of progressive symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve thickening and calcification result in aortic stenosis. This condition typically remains asymptomatic for years, but exertional angina and dyspnea can develop gradually as the aortic valve becomes increasingly stenotic. If the stenosis becomes severe, patients can experience symptoms at rest. Aortic stenosis is not likely to initially manifest with sudden-onset symptoms that do not improve with rest as seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Disruption of an atherosclerotic plaque with a nonocclusive coronary artery thrombus can impair coronary artery perfusion and result in myocardial ischemia that causes unstable angina pectoris. This condition includes new-onset angina pectoris and angina pectoris that increases in frequency or severity over time. Symptoms typically persist for ≥ 20 minutes and can occur at rest or with minimal exertion as seen in this case. Unstable angina pectoris does not cause cardiac biomarker elevation. ECG can be normal or show ST depression and/or T-wave inversion.

Key learning point: Unstable angina is caused by disruption of an atherosclerotic plaque with a nonocclusive coronary artery thrombus, resulting in ischemic chest pain without elevation of cardiac biomarkers.

E) INCORRECT:

An atherosclerotic plaque thrombus with complete coronary artery occlusion results in myocardial infarction (e.g., STEMI, NSTEMI), which manifests with chest pain and dyspnea. However, myocardial infarction causes increased serum concentrations of cardiac biomarkers such as troponin, which are not seen in this patient. Moreover, myocardial infarction is usually associated with characteristic ECG changes (e.g., ST elevation, ST depression).
questions.hint: This patient with multiple cardiovascular risk factors (older age, male sex, history of diabetes mellitus and smoking) has unstable angina pectoris, a condition that can cause chest pain and dyspnea at rest without cardiac biomarker elevation.

questions.text: You are seeing a 65-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of acute chest pain. He has a history of hypertension and is currently taking atorvastatin and lisinopril. On arrival, he appears pale and diaphoretic. His pulse is 114/min and blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg. Electrocardiography shows ST-segment depressions in leads II, III, and aVF. Laboratory studies reveal an increased serum troponin T concentration. He is treated for acute coronary syndrome and undergoes percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty with stent placement. At discharge, echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 58%. In addition to aspirin, which one of the following drugs should be added to his medication regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine therapy is associated with increased mortality after acute myocardial infarction; therefore, it should be avoided in the acute management of coronary artery disease. Nifedipine can be added as an adjunct to beta blockers in patients with stable ischemic heart disease.

B) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) improve mortality and left ventricular ejection fraction after acute coronary syndrome. Initiation of treatment with an ACE inhibitor or ARB is recommended for stable patients within the first 24 hours after the onset of symptoms. However, this patient already receives lisinopril therapy, and combination therapy with both an ACE inhibitor and an ARB is not recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Treatment with an aldosterone receptor antagonist such as spironolactone is indicated following acute myocardial infarction in patients with left ventricular dysfunction (LVEF ≤ 40%) who develop symptoms of congestive heart failure (e.g., paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, lower extremity edema) or have a history of diabetes mellitus. This patient does not meet the criteria for treatment with spironolactone.

D) CORRECT:

Long-term dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (e.g., clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor) is the recommended regimen for all patients after reperfusion therapy. DAPT reduces mortality and the risk of developing subsequent ischemic episodes and stent thrombosis. The duration of DAPT is an individual decision based on bleeding risk and the risk of stent thrombosis. After PCI with stent placement, DAPT is usually recommended for 12 months. In addition to DAPT, long-term pharmacotherapy for secondary prevention after acute coronary syndrome consists of an ACE inhibitor, beta blocker, nitrate, and high-dose statin therapy. Low-dose aspirin therapy is continued lifelong.

Key learning point: After percutaneous coronary intervention, dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor (such as clopidogrel) is recommended for at least 12 months to reduce the risk of stent thrombosis and recurrent ischemic events.

E) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation therapy is indicated in the management of acute coronary syndrome. For patients treated with fibrinolytic therapy, enoxaparin is appropriate; unfractionated heparin or bivalirudin are preferred for patients undergoing PTCA. Anticoagulation is not indicated after discharge from the hospital.
questions.hint: This patient had an acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and underwent percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) with stent placement. His discharge medication regimen should be directed at reducing the risk of subsequent ischemic events and mortality.

questions.text: You are seeing a 69-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain and vomiting that began 30 minutes ago while he was gardening. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. On examination, he is diaphoretic and has jugular venous distention. Electrocardiography shows P waves independent of QRS complexes and ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Which one of the following vessels is most likely to show narrowing on coronary angiography?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the posterior interventricular artery would cause a posterior wall myocardial infarction, which would manifest as ST segment depression in leads V1 and V2, sometimes with prominent R waves. Posterior leads (V7– V9) would show ST segment elevation. Epigastric pain is not common in posterior wall myocardial infarctions, nor are conduction abnormalities, since the posterior interventricular artery does not supply the conduction system.

B) INCORRECT:

The left circumflex artery (LCX) supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle. Occlusion of the LCX causes ECG changes in the lateral (V5, V6, I, aVL) leads. In patients with left-dominant coronary circulation, occlusion of the LCX causes distal infarction of the posterior descending artery, leading to an inferior wall myocardial infarction and ECG changes in the posterior/posterolateral (V7–V9) and inferior (II, III, aVF) leads. However, the LCX is not the most likely source of this patient's inferior wall myocardial infarction because only approx. 10% of the population is left-dominant.

C) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) causes infarction of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), and/or apical wall (leads I, aVL, and V3– V5). The inferior wall is not typically supplied by the LAD. Moreover, although an anteroseptal myocardial infarction can sometimes cause serious arrhythmias, such as a high-degree atrioventricular block (the LAD supplies the left and right bundle branches and partially supplies the left anterior and posterior fascicles), conduction abnormalities are more common following an inferior myocardial infarction.

D) CORRECT:

Occlusion of the proximal right coronary artery (RCA) can cause an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which in turn can present atypically with epigastric pain. High-degree atrioventricular block can occur in this setting because the sinoatrial node (SA node) and atrioventricular node (AV node) are usually supplied by the RCA (the SA node directly, and the AV node via the AV nodal branch). Right-sided leads (V4R, V5R, and V6R) should also be obtained to evaluate for right ventricular (RV) infarction (especially given the patient's jugular venous distention), as the RCA supplies the RV via its right marginal branch.

Key learning point: Inferior wall myocardial infarction with ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is most commonly due to occlusion of the proximal right coronary artery.
Image Description:

This image shows the anatomical location of the coronary arteries from a ventral and dorsal view. The left and right coronary arteries arise from the aortic sinus and run along the corresponding coronary sinuses on the caudal side of the heart. The majority of the population has right-dominant coronary artery circulation.

E) INCORRECT:

The left coronary artery (LCA) branches to the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and the left circumflex artery (LCX). Occlusion of the LCA can lead to a massive myocardial infarction involving a combination of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), apical (leads I, aVL, V3– V5), and posterolateral (leads II, III, aVF, and V5– V7, and sometimes lead I and aVL) walls. This patient's ECG is consistent with infarction of the inferior wall, which can be supplied by the distal LCX but is more commonly supplied by a different artery.
questions.hint: Epigastric pain and vomiting, combined with ST segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF are consistent with an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Dissociated P waves and QRS complexes are indicative of third-degree atrioventricular block.

questions.text: You are seeing a 55-year-old man in the emergency department with a dry cough and severe chest pain that began this morning. He was diagnosed with an inferior wall myocardial infarction two months ago. His temperature is 38.5°C, pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, there is a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while he is sitting upright and during expiration. The remainder of the examination is normal. Electrocardiography shows diffuse ST elevations. Serum troponin I is 200 ng/L (≤ 45). Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis has, on rare occasions, been reported after MI. However, it is a late complication that develops months to years after MI. Moreover, it would manifest with edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, hypotension, increased jugular venous pressure, a pericardial knock, the Kussmaul sign, and pulsus paradoxus, none of which are seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome), a type of postcardiac injury syndrome, usually occurs 2–10 weeks after MI due to immune-complex mediated damage (type III hypersensitivity reaction) in the pericardium. The exact mechanism of immune-complex formation in Dressler syndrome is not completely understood, but the release of neo-antigens from the infarcted myocardium is suspected to play a role. Patients typically present with features of acute pericarditis such as fever, tachypnea, chest pain that is worse during inspiration and relieved by leaning forward, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), a pericardial rub, increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG. Dressler syndrome may also cause pericardial effusion.

Dressler syndrome is treated with NSAIDs, preferably high-dose aspirin.

Key learning point: Dressler syndrome is an immune-mediated pericarditis occurring 2–10 weeks after myocardial infarction, presenting with chest pain, fever, pericardial rub, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade can result from cardiac wall rupture, a complication of myocardial infarction. Cardiac tamponade would result in acute-onset chest pain and tachypnea, as in this patient, and ventricular free wall rupture can also result in increased troponin levels. However, patients with cardiac tamponade would also have features such as dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, and increased jugular venous pressure. On auscultation, muffled heart sounds rather than a pericardial rub would be heard. An ECG would show low voltage complexes, electrical alternans, and, possibly, tall precordial T waves. Moreover, rupture of the cardiac wall typically occurs within 2 weeks after an MI and is more commonly seen in anterior and/or lateral wall infarcts than with inferior wall infarcts.

D) INCORRECT:

Early infarct-associated pericarditis can manifest with fever, tachypnea, chest pain, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST-elevation on ECG. However, early infarct-associated pericarditis typically occurs within a few days after MI, whereas this patient's MI occurred 2 months ago.

E) INCORRECT:

Reinfarction, which is an important consideration in any patient with a recent MI, can manifest with acute-onset chest pain, tachypnea, increased troponin levels, and ST elevations. A dry cough (cardiac asthma) may also be present in some patients with MI. However, a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while sitting upright and during expiration would not be expected in reinfarction. Moreover, the ST elevations would be localized to certain leads, in contrast to the diffuse ST elevations in this patient.
questions.hint: The timing of this patient's symptoms in relation to his recent myocardial infarction (MI), the high-pitched scratching sound heard on auscultation, and the presence of diffuse ST elevations suggest a particular diagnosis.

questions.text: Seventy-two hours after being admitted for an acute myocardial infarction, a 48-year-old man under your care develops dyspnea and a productive cough with frothy sputum. On examination, you find coarse crackles in both lungs and a blowing, holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. Electrocardiography shows Q waves in the anteroseptal leads. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is elevated. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his current condition?

choices.text: Rupture of the ventricular free wall.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the interventricular septum may occur within the first 2 weeks after MI and typically presents with sudden hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia), dyspnea, and new-onset holosystolic murmur. However, because blood is shunted from left to right, patients typically present with signs of right heart failure (e.g., increased JVP, peripheral edema) rather than the signs of isolated left heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, elevated PCWP) seen here. Moreover, the expected murmur would be heard best over the left sternal border, not the apex.

B) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome is a type of pericarditis that arises from an autoimmune reaction to exposed myocardial antigens after acute MI. Patients present with dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, this syndrome would manifest 2–10 weeks after an MI rather than 72 hours as seen in this patient. Furthermore, fever is usually present, cardiac auscultation would reveal a pericardial friction rub, and ECG would show ST elevations in all leads.

C) INCORRECT:

Ventricular wall rupture can occur within 2 weeks of myocardial infarction and typically results in hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade, which can manifest with profound right heart failure, shock, and often death. While free wall rupture and cardiac tamponade can also cause acute pulmonary edema, additional expected findings would include pulsus paradoxus and muffled heart sounds, none of which is observed in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic root dilation can occur in postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis, which commonly manifests 1–3 days after MI. Patients with aortic root dilation present with features of aortic regurgitation. These patients have diastolic, not systolic, murmurs. Moreover, this patient is missing other symptoms of pericarditis, such as chest pain and a friction rub.

E) CORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture most commonly occurs 2–7 days after acute myocardial infarction and is due to extensive coagulative necrosis and the formation of granulation tissue at the area of infarction. This patient's localization of Q waves in the anteroseptal leads (e.g., V1–V4) suggests an infarction of the left anterior descending artery, which supplies the anterolateral papillary muscle. Acute mitral regurgitation can lead to signs of heart failure, as seen in this patient. The posteromedial papillary muscle is supplied only by the posterior descending artery and is at especially high risk of ischemia due to lack of collateral supply.

Key learning point: Papillary muscle rupture 2–7 days after myocardial infarction can cause acute mitral regurgitation, leading to pulmonary edema and a new holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex.
questions.hint: This patient's new murmur (blowing, holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex) and evidence of heart failure (dyspnea, bilateral crackles, elevated capillary wedge pressure) suggest acute mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: You are seeing a 74-year-old woman in your clinic for follow-up. Eight months ago, she underwent emergency cardiac catheterization with stenting for a myocardial infarction. At discharge, her heart configuration was normal, end-diastolic volume was 300 mL, and ejection fraction was 51%. Over the past 6 weeks, she has experienced increasing shortness of breath on exertion. She has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease, but reports rarely taking her medication. Echocardiography now shows left ventricular thinning and dilation, increased end-diastolic volume, and decreased ejection fraction. Which one of the following is most likely to have prevented her worsening ventricular function?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine has been found to worsen symptoms and hemodynamic status in patients with HF and reduced ejection fraction. Although recent studies have shown attenuated cardiac remodeling when nifedipine is used, there are alternative drugs that have been established as first-line therapy for cardiac remodeling prevention.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is usually added to baseline treatment with furosemide in patients with HF who do not achieve sufficient diuresis with loop diuretics alone. Thiazides are used for symptom relief, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) such as diltiazem have not been found to improve mortality and/or remodeling in patients with HF secondary to myocardial infarction. CCBs are mainly used for symptomatic treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Although inotropic agents such as digoxin improve hemodynamic function in patients with HF, it is mainly used for symptom improvement, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

E) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as enalapril have been found to decrease cardiac remodeling by slowing down the rate of left ventricular thinning and dilation after acute MI. This effect is achieved by decreasing preload and afterload due to blockage of angiotensin II. This patient's presentation with dyspnea on exertion, left ventricular dilation on echocardiogram, and a decrease in ejection fraction is consistent with mild to moderate HF.

Indications for ACE inhibitors (and angiotensin II receptor antagonists) in the secondary prevention of MI include heart failure, left ventricular ejection fraction < 40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, stable chronic kidney disease, and ST-segment elevation MI (especially with anterior location). Beta blockers have also been shown to have anti-remodeling effects.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors reduce cardiac remodeling and progression to heart failure after myocardial infarction by inhibiting angiotensin II, thereby decreasing preload and afterload.
questions.hint: This woman did not adhere to her medication regimen after a myocardial infarction (MI). She now presents with dyspnea on exertion, reduced ejection fraction, and left ventricular thinning and dilation, which is consistent with heart failure (HF), most likely due to unhindered cardiac remodeling.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up 4 weeks after being discharged from hospital for treatment of a myocardial infarction. He reports feeling well but has occasional shortness of breath with activity around his house. He denies chest pain or dizziness. Vital signs are normal. On cardiac examination, you hear an S3 gallop and a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. Electrocardiography shows persistent ST elevations and deep Q waves in leads V1 through V4. Echocardiography reveals dyskinesia and outpouching of a region of the left anterior ventricular wall. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperacute (flash) pulmonary edema can be caused by acute severe mitral regurgitation due to papillary muscle rupture following an MI. However, papillary muscle rupture usually occurs 2–7 days after MI, and this patient's MI occurred 4 weeks ago. While a ventricular aneurysm, which this patient has, can lead to heart failure and pulmonary edema, the process is usually subacute and does not lead to hyperacute pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute pericardial effusion can develop in patients with antibody-mediated pericarditis (Dressler syndrome), which can occur several weeks after an MI. This patient, however, has no findings suggestive of pericarditis (e.g., pleuritic chest pain, fever, pericardial friction rub on auscultation, diffuse ST elevations). While he is at risk of pericardial effusion due to ventricular aneurysm rupture, this process would develop acutely, not subacutely.

C) INCORRECT:

A left-to-right shunt can occur as a result of interventricular septal rupture after an MI. However, interventricular septal rupture commonly develops within 3–5 days of an MI, whereas this patient's MI occurred 4 weeks ago. Moreover, his echocardiogram shows dyskinesia of the left anterior ventricular wall but no interventricular septum motion abnormalities; patients with ventricular septal aneurysms have an increased risk of septal rupture.

D) CORRECT:

Ventricular aneurysms can develop several weeks to months after MI because of scar tissue formation that leads to thinning and weakening of the ventricular wall. The relative stasis of blood flow within the aneurysmal segment can cause a mural thrombus to form and embolize to distal locations, leading to ischemic events (e.g., stroke, mesenteric ischemia, renal infarction, acute limb ischemia). Other complications of a ventricular aneurysm include heart failure, ventricular arrhythmias, and myocardial rupture, which can lead to cardiac tamponade.

Small or asymptomatic aneurysms can be managed conservatively (e.g., serial imaging to monitor aneurysm size, treatment of heart failure if present). Oral anticoagulation is indicated in all patients with a left ventricular thrombus. Aneurysmectomy is usually reserved for symptomatic patients who do not respond adequately to medical treatment.

Key learning point: Ventricular aneurysm following myocardial infarction increases the risk of mural thrombus formation, which can lead to systemic embolic complications such as stroke or limb ischemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Septic embolization may occur as a complication of infective endocarditis if vegetations embolize to other parts of the body. This patient's systolic murmur is consistent with mitral regurgitation, which puts him at risk of developing infective endocarditis. However, he does not have typical features of endocarditis, such as fever or findings of vegetations on echocardiography.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG findings of persistent ST elevations in the anterior chest leads along with outpouching of a discrete region within the left anterior ventricular wall suggest a ventricular aneurysm, a late complication of myocardial infarction (MI). In patients with a left ventricular aneurysm, a systolic murmur might be heard as a result of mitral regurgitation due to the distortion of the ventricle's geometry. A third heart sound is also common in patients with ventricular aneurysms.

questions.text: You are working in the emergency department when a 61-year-old man is brought in by ambulance because of severe retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for 30 minutes. Paramedics report that an ECG recorded en route showed ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, and the precordial leads. On arrival, he is unresponsive to painful stimuli, with no respiration or pulse. Despite appropriate resuscitation efforts, he dies 10 minutes later. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In ventricular aneurysm, a portion of the ventricular free wall affected by the MI will outpouch, putting patients at risk for cardiac arrhythmia, heart failure, and cardiac tamponade, all of which can cause sudden cardiac death. However, ventricular aneurysm happens between 2 weeks and several months after MI.

B) CORRECT:

Ventricular fibrillation is a cardiac arrhythmia in which multiple ectopic foci of electrical activity within the ventricle cause disorganized depolarization and diminished cardiac output. Patients with ventricular fibrillation require rapid defibrillation and CPR, otherwise hemodynamic instability can lead to loss of consciousness and SCD, which is the leading cause of death post-MI. SCD after MI is usually due to ventricular tachyarrhythmias such as ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation.

Key learning point: Ventricular fibrillation is the most common early cause of sudden cardiac death following acute myocardial infarction.

C) INCORRECT:

MI that affects the interventricular septum has the potential to rupture, creating a left-to-right shunt and right heart failure. While this would also present with shortness of breath, it would usually not occur until 3–5 days after MI.

D) INCORRECT:

Thromboembolism can result from left ventricular aneurysm or new onset atrial fibrillation post-MI and can cause hemorrhagic stroke. However, these complications typically take days to weeks to develop, and stroke is not a common cause of sudden cardiac death in patients with MI.

E) INCORRECT:

MI can cause weakness of the ventricular free wall, which makes it prone to rupture under the high pressures of systole. This results in cardiac tamponade and is often fatal. However, ventricular free wall rupture occurs usually within the first 2 weeks of MI, when necrosis has had time to sufficiently weaken the ventricular free wall tissue, not during first hour post-MI.
questions.hint: The patient's chest pain and dyspnea combined with the finding of ST-segment elevation in a proximal left anterior descending distribution on ECG are highly suggestive of myocardial infarction (MI). The patient's subsequent death within an hour of symptom onset is known as sudden cardiac death (SCD).

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with diabetes and hypertension presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of nausea, diaphoresis, and epigastric discomfort. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 90; oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination shows pallor and cool, clammy skin. Point of care glucose is 100 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CBC does not provide immediate diagnostic information for suspected acute coronary syndrome. While CBC may be obtained as part of routine laboratory studies to evaluate for anemia or thrombocytopenia that could affect management decisions, it is not the most appropriate next diagnostic test in a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of myocardial infarction.

B) INCORRECT:

Influenza rapid antigen testing is not indicated in this clinical presentation. The symptom constellation in an elderly diabetic woman is more suggestive of a cardiac etiology requiring immediate evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Chest x-ray does not provide immediate diagnostic information for suspected acute coronary syndrome. While chest imaging may be useful later to evaluate for complications such as pulmonary edema, it is not the most appropriate next diagnostic test in a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of myocardial infarction.

D) CORRECT:
